        <td id="LC1074" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">no monarch in an oriental sense, and the chosen leaders of the Greeks</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1075" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1075"></td>
        <td id="LC1075" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">never, until the late days, arrogated art to themselves. It was</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1076" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1076"></td>
        <td id="LC1076" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">something for all the people.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1077" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1077"></td>
        <td id="LC1077" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1078" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1078"></td>
        <td id="LC1078" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">In religion there was a pantheon of gods established and worshipped</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1079" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1079"></td>
        <td id="LC1079" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">from the earliest ages, but these gods were more like epitomes of</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1080" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1080"></td>
        <td id="LC1080" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Greek ideals than spiritual beings. They were the personified virtues</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1081" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1081"></td>
        <td id="LC1081" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">of the Greeks, exemplars of perfect living; and in worshipping them</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1082" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1082"></td>
        <td id="LC1082" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">the Greek was really worshipping order, conduct, repose, dignity,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1083" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1083"></td>
        <td id="LC1083" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">perfect life. The gods and heroes, as types of moral and physical</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1084" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1084"></td>
        <td id="LC1084" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">qualities, were continually represented in an allegorical or legendary</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1085" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1085"></td>
        <td id="LC1085" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">manner. Athene represented noble warfare, Zeus was majestic dignity</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1086" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1086"></td>
        <td id="LC1086" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">and power, Aphrodite love, Phoebus song, Nike triumph, and all the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1087" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1087"></td>
        <td id="LC1087" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">lesser gods, nymphs, and fauns stood for beauties of nature or of</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1088" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1088"></td>
        <td id="LC1088" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">life. The great bulk of Greek architecture, sculpture, and painting</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1089" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1089"></td>
        <td id="LC1089" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">was put forth to honor these gods or heroes, and by so doing the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1090" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1090"></td>
        <td id="LC1090" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">artist repeated the national ideals and honored himself. The first</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1091" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1091"></td>
        <td id="LC1091" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">motive of Greek art, then, was to praise Hellas and the Hellenic view</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1092" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1092"></td>
        <td id="LC1092" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">of life. In part it was a religious motive, but with little of that</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1093" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1093"></td>
        <td id="LC1093" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">spiritual significance and belief which ruled in Egypt, and later on</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1094" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1094"></td>
        <td id="LC1094" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">in Italy.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1095" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1095"></td>
        <td id="LC1095" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1096" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1096"></td>
        <td id="LC1096" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">[Illustration: FIG. 11.--ATTIC GRAVE PAINTING. (FROM BAUMEISTER.)]</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1097" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1097"></td>
        <td id="LC1097" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1098" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1098"></td>
        <td id="LC1098" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">A second and ever-present motive in Greek painting was decoration.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1099" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1099"></td>
        <td id="LC1099" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">This appears in the tomb pottery of the earliest ages, and was carried</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1100" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1100"></td>
        <td id="LC1100" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">on down to the latest times. Vase painting, wall painting, tablet and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1101" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1101"></td>
        <td id="LC1101" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">sculpture painting were all done with a decorative motive in view.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1102" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1102"></td>
        <td id="LC1102" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Even the easel or panel pictures had some decorative effect about</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1103" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1103"></td>
        <td id="LC1103" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">them, though they were primarily intended to convey ideas other than</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1104" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1104"></td>
        <td id="LC1104" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">those of form and color.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1105" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1105"></td>
        <td id="LC1105" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1106" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1106"></td>
        <td id="LC1106" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">SUBJECTS AND METHODS: The gods and heroes, their lives and adventures,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1107" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1107"></td>
        <td id="LC1107" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">formed the early subjects of Greek painting. Certain themes taken</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1108" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1108"></td>
        <td id="LC1108" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">from the &quot;Iliad&quot; and the &quot;Odyssey&quot; were as frequently shown as,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1109" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1109"></td>
        <td id="LC1109" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">afterward, the Annunciations in Italian painting. The traditional</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1110" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1110"></td>
        <td id="LC1110" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">subjects, the Centaurs and Lapiths, the Amazon war, Theseus and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1111" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1111"></td>
        <td id="LC1111" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Ariadne, Perseus and Andromeda, were frequently depicted. Humanity and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1112" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1112"></td>
        <td id="LC1112" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">actual Greek life came in for its share. Single figures, still-life,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1113" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1113"></td>
        <td id="LC1113" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">_genre_, caricature, all were shown, and as painting neared the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1114" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1114"></td>
        <td id="LC1114" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Alexandrian age a semi-realistic portraiture came into vogue.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1115" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1115"></td>
        <td id="LC1115" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1116" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1116"></td>
        <td id="LC1116" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">The materials employed by the Greeks and their methods of work are</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1117" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1117"></td>
        <td id="LC1117" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">somewhat difficult to ascertain, because there are few Greek pictures,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1118" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1118"></td>
        <td id="LC1118" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">except those on the vases, left to us. From the confusing accounts of</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1119" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1119"></td>
        <td id="LC1119" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">the ancient writers, the vases, some Greek slabs in Italy, and the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1120" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1120"></td>
        <td id="LC1120" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Roman paintings imitative of the Greek, we may gain a general idea.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1121" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1121"></td>
        <td id="LC1121" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">The early Greek work was largely devoted to pottery and tomb</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1122" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1122"></td>
        <td id="LC1122" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">decoration, in which much in manner and method was borrowed from Asia,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1123" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1123"></td>
        <td id="LC1123" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Phoenicia, and Egypt. Later on, painting appeared in flat outline on</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1124" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1124"></td>
        <td id="LC1124" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">stone or terra-cotta slabs, sometimes representing processional</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1125" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1125"></td>
        <td id="LC1125" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">scenes, as in Egypt, and doubtless done in a hybrid fresco-work</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1126" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1126"></td>
        <td id="LC1126" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">similar to the Egyptian method. Wall paintings were done in fresco and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1127" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1127"></td>
        <td id="LC1127" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">distemper, probably upon the walls themselves, and also upon panels</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1128" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1128"></td>
        <td id="LC1128" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">afterward let into the wall. Encaustic painting (color mixed with wax</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1129" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1129"></td>
        <td id="LC1129" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">upon the panel and fused with a hot spatula) came in with the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1130" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1130"></td>
        <td id="LC1130" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Sikyonian school. It is possible that the oil medium and canvas were</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1131" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1131"></td>
        <td id="LC1131" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">known, but not probable that either was ever used extensively.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1132" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1132"></td>
        <td id="LC1132" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1133" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1133"></td>
        <td id="LC1133" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">There is no doubt about the Greeks being expert draughtsmen, though</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1134" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1134"></td>
        <td id="LC1134" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">this does not appear until late in history. They knew the outlines</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1135" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1135"></td>
        <td id="LC1135" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">well, and drew them with force and grace. That they modelled in strong</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1136" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1136"></td>
        <td id="LC1136" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">relief is more questionable. Light-and-shade was certainly employed in</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1137" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1137"></td>
        <td id="LC1137" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">the figure, but not in any modern way. Perspective in both figures and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1138" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1138"></td>
        <td id="LC1138" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">landscape was used; but the landscape was at first symbolic and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1139" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1139"></td>
        <td id="LC1139" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">rarely got beyond a decorative background for the figure. Greek</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1140" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1140"></td>
        <td id="LC1140" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">composition we know little about, but may infer that it was largely a</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1141" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1141"></td>
        <td id="LC1141" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">series of balances, a symmetrical adjustment of objects to fill a</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1142" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1142"></td>
        <td id="LC1142" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">given space with not very much freedom allowed to the artist. In</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1143" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1143"></td>
        <td id="LC1143" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">atmosphere, sunlight, color, and those peculiarly sensuous charms that</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1144" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1144"></td>
        <td id="LC1144" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">belong to painting, there is no reason to believe that the Greeks</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1145" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1145"></td>
        <td id="LC1145" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">approached the moderns. Their interest was chiefly centred in the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1146" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1146"></td>
        <td id="LC1146" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">human figure. Landscape, with its many beauties, was reserved for</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1147" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1147"></td>
        <td id="LC1147" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">modern hands to disclose. Color was used in abundance, without doubt,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1148" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1148"></td>
        <td id="LC1148" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">but it was probably limited to the leading hues, with little of that</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1149" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1149"></td>
        <td id="LC1149" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">refinement or delicacy known in painting to-day.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1150" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1150"></td>
        <td id="LC1150" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1151" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1151"></td>
        <td id="LC1151" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">ART HISTORY: For the history of Greek painting we have to rely upon</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1152" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1152"></td>
        <td id="LC1152" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">the words of Aristotle, Plutarch, Pliny, Quintilian, Lucian, Cicero,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1153" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1153"></td>
        <td id="LC1153" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Pausanias. Their accounts appear to be partly substantiated by the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1154" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1154"></td>
        <td id="LC1154" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">vase paintings, and such few slabs and Roman frescos as remain to us.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1155" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1155"></td>
        <td id="LC1155" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">There is no consecutive narrative. The story of painting originating</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1156" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1156"></td>
        <td id="LC1156" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">from a girl seeing the wall-silhouette of her lover and filling it in</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1157" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1157"></td>
        <td id="LC1157" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">with color, and the conjecture of painting having developed from</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1158" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1158"></td>
        <td id="LC1158" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">embroidery work, have neither of them a foundation in fact. The</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1159" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1159"></td>
        <td id="LC1159" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">earliest settlers of Greece probably learned painting from the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1160" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1160"></td>
        <td id="LC1160" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Phoenicians, and employed it, after the Egyptian, Assyrian, and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1161" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1161"></td>
        <td id="LC1161" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Phoenician manner, on pottery, terra-cotta slabs, and rude</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1162" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1162"></td>
        <td id="LC1162" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">sculpture. It developed slower than sculpture perhaps; but were there</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1163" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1163"></td>
        <td id="LC1163" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">anything of importance left to judge from, we should probably find</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1164" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1164"></td>
        <td id="LC1164" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">that it developed in much the same manner as sculpture. Down to 500</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1165" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1165"></td>
        <td id="LC1165" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">B.C. there was little more than outline filled in with flat</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1166" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1166"></td>
        <td id="LC1166" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">monochromatic paint and with a decorative effect similar, perhaps, to</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1167" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1167"></td>
        <td id="LC1167" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">that of the vase paintings. After that date come the more important</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1168" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1168"></td>
        <td id="LC1168" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">names of artists mentioned by the ancient writers. It is difficult to</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1169" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1169"></td>
        <td id="LC1169" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">assign these artists to certain periods or schools, owing to the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1170" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1170"></td>
        <td id="LC1170" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">insufficient knowledge we have about them. The following</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1171" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1171"></td>
        <td id="LC1171" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">classifications and assignments may, therefore, in some instances, be</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1172" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1172"></td>
        <td id="LC1172" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">questioned.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1173" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1173"></td>
        <td id="LC1173" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1174" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1174"></td>
        <td id="LC1174" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">[Illustration: FIG. 12.--MUSE OF CORTONA, CORTONA MUSEUM.]</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1175" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1175"></td>
        <td id="LC1175" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1176" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1176"></td>
        <td id="LC1176" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">OLDER ATTIC SCHOOL: The first painter of rank was Polygnotus (fl.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1177" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1177"></td>
        <td id="LC1177" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">475-455 B.C.), sometimes called the founder of Greek painting, because</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1178" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1178"></td>
        <td id="LC1178" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">perhaps he was one of the first important painters in Greece proper.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1179" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1179"></td>
        <td id="LC1179" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">He seems to have been a good outline draughtsman, producing figures in</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1180" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1180"></td>
        <td id="LC1180" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">profile, with little attempt at relief, perspective, or</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1181" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1181"></td>
        <td id="LC1181" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">light-and-shade. His colors were local tones, but probably more like</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1182" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1182"></td>
        <td id="LC1182" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">nature and more varied than anything in Egyptian painting. Landscapes,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1183" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1183"></td>
        <td id="LC1183" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">buildings, and the like, were given in a symbolic manner. Portraiture</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1184" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1184"></td>
        <td id="LC1184" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">was a generalization, and in figure compositions the names of the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1185" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1185"></td>
        <td id="LC1185" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">principal characters were written near them for purposes of</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1186" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1186"></td>
        <td id="LC1186" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">identification. The most important works of Polygnotus were the wall</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1187" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1187"></td>
        <td id="LC1187" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">paintings for the Assembly Room of the Knidians at Delphi. The</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1188" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1188"></td>
        <td id="LC1188" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">subjects related to the Trojan War and the adventures of Ulysses.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1189" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1189"></td>
        <td id="LC1189" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1190" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1190"></td>
        <td id="LC1190" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Opposed to this flat, unrelieved style was the work of a follower,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1191" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1191"></td>
        <td id="LC1191" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Agatharchos of Samos (fl. end of fifth century B.C.). He was a</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1192" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1192"></td>
        <td id="LC1192" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">scene-painter, and by the necessities of his craft was led toward</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1193" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1193"></td>
        <td id="LC1193" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">nature. Stage effect required a study of perspective, variation of</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1194" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1194"></td>
        <td id="LC1194" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">light, and a knowledge of the laws of optics. The slight outline</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1195" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1195"></td>
        <td id="LC1195" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">drawing of his predecessor was probably superseded by effective masses</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1196" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1196"></td>
        <td id="LC1196" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">to create illusion. This was a distinct advance toward nature.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1197" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1197"></td>
        <td id="LC1197" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Apollodorus (fl. end of fifth century B.C.) applied the principles of</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1198" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1198"></td>
        <td id="LC1198" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Agatharchos to figures. According to Plutarch, he was the first to</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1199" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1199"></td>
        <td id="LC1199" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">discover variation in the shade of colors, and, according to Pliny,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1200" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1200"></td>
        <td id="LC1200" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">the first master to paint objects as they appeared in nature. He had</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1201" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1201"></td>
        <td id="LC1201" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">the title of _skiagraphos_ (shadow-painter), and possibly gave a</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1202" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1202"></td>
        <td id="LC1202" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">semi-natural background with perspective. This was an improvement, but</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1203" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1203"></td>
        <td id="LC1203" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">not a perfection. It is not likely that the backgrounds were other</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1204" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1204"></td>
        <td id="LC1204" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">than conventional settings for the figure. Even these were not at once</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1205" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1205"></td>
        <td id="LC1205" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">accepted by the painters of the period, but were turned to profit in</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1206" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1206"></td>
        <td id="LC1206" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">the hands of the followers.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1207" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1207"></td>
        <td id="LC1207" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1208" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1208"></td>
        <td id="LC1208" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">After the Peloponnesian Wars the art of painting seems to have</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1209" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1209"></td>
        <td id="LC1209" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">flourished elsewhere than in Athens, owing to the Athenian loss of</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1210" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1210"></td>
        <td id="LC1210" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">supremacy. Other schools sprang up in various districts, and one to</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1211" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1211"></td>
        <td id="LC1211" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">call for considerable mention by the ancient writers was the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1212" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1212"></td>
        <td id="LC1212" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1213" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1213"></td>
        <td id="LC1213" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">IONIAN SCHOOL, which in reality had existed from the sixth century.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1214" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1214"></td>
        <td id="LC1214" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">The painters of this school advanced upon the work of Apollodorus as</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1215" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1215"></td>
        <td id="LC1215" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">regards realistic effect. Zeuxis, whose fame was at its height during</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1216" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1216"></td>
        <td id="LC1216" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">the Peloponnesian Wars, seems to have regarded art as a matter of</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1217" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1217"></td>
        <td id="LC1217" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">illusion, if one may judge by the stories told of his work. The tale</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1218" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1218"></td>
        <td id="LC1218" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">of his painting a bunch of grapes so like reality that the birds came</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1219" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1219"></td>
        <td id="LC1219" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">to peck at them proves either that the painter&#39;s motive was deception,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1220" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1220"></td>
        <td id="LC1220" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">or that the narrator of the tale picked out the deceptive part of his</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1221" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1221"></td>
        <td id="LC1221" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">picture for admiration. He painted many subjects, like Helen,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1222" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1222"></td>
        <td id="LC1222" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Penelope, and many _genre_ pieces on panel. Quintilian says he</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1223" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1223"></td>
        <td id="LC1223" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">originated light-and-shade, an achievement credited by Plutarch to</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1224" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1224"></td>
        <td id="LC1224" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Apollodorus. It is probable that he advanced light-and-shade.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1225" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1225"></td>
        <td id="LC1225" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1226" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1226"></td>
        <td id="LC1226" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">In illusion he seems to have been outdone by a rival, Parrhasios of</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1227" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1227"></td>
        <td id="LC1227" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Ephesus. Zeuxis deceived the birds with painted grapes, but Parrhasios</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1228" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1228"></td>
        <td id="LC1228" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">deceived Zeuxis with a painted curtain. There must have been knowledge</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1229" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1229"></td>
        <td id="LC1229" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">of color, modelling, and relief to have produced such an illusion, but</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1230" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1230"></td>
        <td id="LC1230" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">the aim was petty and unworthy of the skill. There was evidently an</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1231" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1231"></td>
        <td id="LC1231" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">advance technically, but some decline in the true spirit of art.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1232" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1232"></td>
        <td id="LC1232" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Parrhasios finally suffered defeat at the hands of Timanthes of</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1233" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1233"></td>
        <td id="LC1233" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Kythnos, by a Contest between Ajax and Ulysses for the Arms of</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1234" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1234"></td>
        <td id="LC1234" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Achilles. Timanthes&#39;s famous work was the Sacrifice of Iphigenia, of</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1235" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1235"></td>
        <td id="LC1235" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">which there is a supposed Pompeian copy.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1236" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1236"></td>
        <td id="LC1236" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1237" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1237"></td>
        <td id="LC1237" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">SIKYONIAN SCHOOL: This school seems to have sprung up after the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1238" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1238"></td>
        <td id="LC1238" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Peloponnesian Wars, and was perhaps founded by Eupompos, a</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1239" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1239"></td>
        <td id="LC1239" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">contemporary of Parrhasios. His pupil Pamphilos brought the school to</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1240" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1240"></td>
        <td id="LC1240" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">maturity. He apparently reacted from the deception motive of Zeuxis</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1241" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1241"></td>
        <td id="LC1241" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">and Parrhasios, and taught academic methods of drawing, composing, and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1242" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1242"></td>
        <td id="LC1242" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">painting. He was also credited with bringing into use the encaustic</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1243" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1243"></td>
        <td id="LC1243" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">method of painting, though it was probably known before his time. His</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1244" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1244"></td>
        <td id="LC1244" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">pupil, Pausias, possessed some freedom of creation in _genre_ and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1245" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1245"></td>
        <td id="LC1245" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">still-life subjects. Pliny says he had great technical skill, as shown</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1246" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1246"></td>
        <td id="LC1246" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">in the foreshortening of a black ox by variations of the black tones,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1247" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1247"></td>
        <td id="LC1247" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">and he obtained some fame by a figure of Methe (Intoxication) drinking</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1248" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1248"></td>
        <td id="LC1248" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">from a glass, the face being seen through the glass. Again the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1249" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1249"></td>
        <td id="LC1249" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">motives seem trifling, but again advancing technical power is shown.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1250" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1250"></td>
        <td id="LC1250" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1251" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1251"></td>
        <td id="LC1251" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">[Illustration: FIG. 13.--ODYSSEY LANDSCAPE, VATICAN. (FROM WOLTMANN AND</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1252" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1252"></td>
        <td id="LC1252" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">WOERMANN.)]</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1253" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1253"></td>
        <td id="LC1253" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1254" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1254"></td>
        <td id="LC1254" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">THEBAN-ATTIC SCHOOL: This was the fourth school of Greek painting.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1255" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1255"></td>
        <td id="LC1255" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Nikomachus (fl. about 360 B.C.), a facile painter, was at its head.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1256" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1256"></td>
        <td id="LC1256" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">His pupil, Aristides, painted pathetic scenes, and was perhaps as</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1257" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1257"></td>
        <td id="LC1257" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">remarkable for teaching art to the celebrated Euphranor (fl. 360 B.C.)</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1258" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1258"></td>
        <td id="LC1258" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">as for his own productions. Euphranor had great versatility in the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1259" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1259"></td>
        <td id="LC1259" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">arts, and in painting was renowned for his pictures of the Olympian</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1260" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1260"></td>
        <td id="LC1260" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">gods at Athens. His successor, Nikias (fl. 340-300 B.C.), was a</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1261" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1261"></td>
        <td id="LC1261" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">contemporary of Praxiteles, the sculptor, and was possibly influenced</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1262" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1262"></td>
        <td id="LC1262" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">by him in the painting of female figures. He was a technician of</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1263" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1263"></td>
        <td id="LC1263" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">ability in composition, light-and-shade, and relief, and was praised</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1264" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1264"></td>
        <td id="LC1264" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">for the roundness of his figures. He also did some tinting of</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1265" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1265"></td>
        <td id="LC1265" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">sculpture, and is said to have tinted some of the works of</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1266" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1266"></td>
        <td id="LC1266" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Praxiteles.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1267" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1267"></td>
        <td id="LC1267" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1268" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1268"></td>
        <td id="LC1268" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">LATE PAINTERS: Contemporary with and following these last-named</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1269" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1269"></td>
        <td id="LC1269" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">artists were some celebrated painters who really belong to the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1270" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1270"></td>
        <td id="LC1270" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">beginning of the Hellenistic Period (323 B.C.). At their head was</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1271" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1271"></td>
        <td id="LC1271" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Apelles, the painter of Philip and Alexander, and the climax of Greek</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1272" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1272"></td>
        <td id="LC1272" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">painting. He painted many gods, heroes, and allegories, with much</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1273" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1273"></td>
        <td id="LC1273" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">&quot;gracefulness,&quot; as Pliny puts it. The Italian Botticelli, seventeen</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1274" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1274"></td>
        <td id="LC1274" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">hundred years after him, tried to reproduce his celebrated Calumny,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1275" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1275"></td>
        <td id="LC1275" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">from Lucian&#39;s description of it. His chief works were his Aphrodite</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1276" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1276"></td>
        <td id="LC1276" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Anadyomene, carried to Rome by Augustus, and the portrait of Alexander</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1277" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1277"></td>
        <td id="LC1277" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">with the Thunder-bolt. He was undoubtedly a superior man technically.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1278" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1278"></td>
        <td id="LC1278" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Protogenes rivalled him, if we are to believe Petronius, by the foam</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1279" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1279"></td>
        <td id="LC1279" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">on a dog&#39;s mouth and the wonder in the eye of a startled pheasant.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1280" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1280"></td>
        <td id="LC1280" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Aetion, the painter of Alexander&#39;s Marriage to Roxana, was not able to</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1281" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1281"></td>
        <td id="LC1281" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">turn the aim of painting from this deceptive illusion. After</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1282" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1282"></td>
        <td id="LC1282" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Alexander, painting passed still further into the imitative and the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1283" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1283"></td>
        <td id="LC1283" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">theatrical, and when not grandiloquent was infinitely little over</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1284" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1284"></td>
        <td id="LC1284" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">cobbler-shops and huckster-stalls. Landscape for purposes of</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1285" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1285"></td>
        <td id="LC1285" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">decorative composition, and floor painting, done in mosaic, came in</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1286" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1286"></td>
        <td id="LC1286" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">during the time of the Diadochi. There were no great names in the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1287" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1287"></td>
        <td id="LC1287" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">latter days, and such painters as still flourished passed on to Rome,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1288" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1288"></td>
        <td id="LC1288" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">there to produce copies of the works of their predecessors.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1289" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1289"></td>
        <td id="LC1289" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1290" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1290"></td>
        <td id="LC1290" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">It is hard to reconcile the unworthy motive attributed to Greek</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1291" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1291"></td>
        <td id="LC1291" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">painting by the ancient writers with the high aim of Greek sculpture.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1292" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1292"></td>
        <td id="LC1292" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">It is easier to think (and it is more probable) that the writers knew</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1293" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1293"></td>
        <td id="LC1293" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">very little about art, and that they missed the spirit of Greek</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1294" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1294"></td>
        <td id="LC1294" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">painting in admiring its insignificant details. That painting</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1295" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1295"></td>
        <td id="LC1295" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">technically was at a high point of perfection as regards the figure,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1296" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1296"></td>
        <td id="LC1296" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">even the imitative Roman works indicate, and it can hardly be doubted</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1297" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1297"></td>
        <td id="LC1297" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">that in spirit it was at one time equally strong.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1298" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1298"></td>
        <td id="LC1298" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1299" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1299"></td>
        <td id="LC1299" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     EXTANT REMAINS: There are few wall or panel pictures of</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1300" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1300"></td>
        <td id="LC1300" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     Greek times in existence. Four slabs of stone in the Naples</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1301" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1301"></td>
        <td id="LC1301" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     Museum, with red outline drawings of Theseus, Silenos, and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1302" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1302"></td>
        <td id="LC1302" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     some figures with masks, are probably Greek work from which</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1303" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1303"></td>
        <td id="LC1303" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     the color has scaled. A number of Roman copies of Greek</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1304" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1304"></td>
        <td id="LC1304" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     frescos and mosaics are in the Vatican, Capitoline, and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1305" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1305"></td>
        <td id="LC1305" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     Naples Museums. All these pieces show an imitation of late</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1306" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1306"></td>
        <td id="LC1306" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     Hellenistic art--not the best period of Greek development.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1307" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1307"></td>
        <td id="LC1307" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1308" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1308"></td>
        <td id="LC1308" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     THE VASES: The history of Greek painting in its remains is</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1309" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1309"></td>
        <td id="LC1309" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     traced with some accuracy in the decorative figures upon the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1310" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1310"></td>
        <td id="LC1310" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     vases. The first ware--dating before the seventh century</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1311" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1311"></td>
        <td id="LC1311" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     B.C.--seems free from oriental influences in its designs.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1312" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1312"></td>
        <td id="LC1312" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     The vase is reddish, the decoration is in tiers, bands, or</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1313" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1313"></td>
        <td id="LC1313" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     zig-zags, usually in black or brown, without the human</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1314" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1314"></td>
        <td id="LC1314" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     figure. The second kind of ware dates from about the middle</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1315" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1315"></td>
        <td id="LC1315" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     of the seventh century. It shows meander, wave, and other</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1316" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1316"></td>
        <td id="LC1316" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     designs, and is called the &quot;geometrical&quot; style. Later on</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1317" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1317"></td>
        <td id="LC1317" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     animals, rosettes, and vegetation appear that show Assyrian</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1318" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1318"></td>
        <td id="LC1318" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     influence. The decoration is profuse and the rude human</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1319" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1319"></td>
        <td id="LC1319" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     figure subordinate to it. The design is in black or</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1320" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1320"></td>
        <td id="LC1320" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     dark-brown, on a cream-colored slip. The third kind of ware</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1321" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1321"></td>
        <td id="LC1321" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     is the archaic or &quot;strong&quot; style. It dates from 500 B.C. to</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1322" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1322"></td>
        <td id="LC1322" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     the Peloponnesian Wars, and is marked by black figures upon</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1323" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1323"></td>
        <td id="LC1323" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     a yellow or red ground. White and purple are also used to</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1324" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1324"></td>
        <td id="LC1324" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     define flesh, hair, and white objects. The figure is stiff,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1325" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1325"></td>
        <td id="LC1325" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     the action awkward, the composition is freer than before,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1326" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1326"></td>
        <td id="LC1326" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     but still conventional. The subjects are the gods,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1327" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1327"></td>
        <td id="LC1327" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     demi-gods, and heroes in scenes from their lives and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1328" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1328"></td>
        <td id="LC1328" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     adventures. The fourth kind of ware dates down into the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1329" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1329"></td>
        <td id="LC1329" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     Hellenistic age and shows red figures surrounded by a black</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1330" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1330"></td>
        <td id="LC1330" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     ground. The figure, the drawing, the composition are better</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1331" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1331"></td>
        <td id="LC1331" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     than at any other period and suggest a high excellence in</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1332" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1332"></td>
        <td id="LC1332" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     other forms of Greek painting. After Alexander, vase</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1333" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1333"></td>
        <td id="LC1333" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     painting seems to have shared the fate of wall and panel</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1334" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1334"></td>
        <td id="LC1334" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     painting. There was a striving for effect, with ornateness</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1335" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1335"></td>
        <td id="LC1335" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     and extravagance, and finally the art passed out entirely.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1336" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1336"></td>
        <td id="LC1336" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1337" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1337"></td>
        <td id="LC1337" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     There was an establishment founded in Southern Italy which</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1338" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1338"></td>
        <td id="LC1338" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     imitated the Greek and produced the Apulian ware, but the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1339" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1339"></td>
        <td id="LC1339" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     Romans gave little encouragement to vase painting, and about</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1340" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1340"></td>
        <td id="LC1340" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     65 B.C. it disappeared. Almost all the museums of the world</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1341" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1341"></td>
        <td id="LC1341" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     have collections of Greek vases. The British, Berlin, and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1342" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1342"></td>
        <td id="LC1342" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     Paris collections are perhaps as complete as any.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1343" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1343"></td>
        <td id="LC1343" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1344" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1344"></td>
        <td id="LC1344" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">[Illustration: FIG. 14.--AMPHORE, LOWER ITALY.]</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1345" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1345"></td>
        <td id="LC1345" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1346" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1346"></td>
        <td id="LC1346" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1347" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1347"></td>
        <td id="LC1347" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">ETRUSCAN AND ROMAN PAINTING.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1348" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1348"></td>
        <td id="LC1348" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1349" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1349"></td>
        <td id="LC1349" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     BOOKS RECOMMENDED: See Bibliography of Greek Painting and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1350" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1350"></td>
        <td id="LC1350" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     also Dennis, _Cities and Cemeteries of Etruria_; Graul, _Die</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1351" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1351"></td>
        <td id="LC1351" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     Portratgemalde aus den Grabstatten des Faiyum_; Helbig, _Die</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1352" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1352"></td>
        <td id="LC1352" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     Wandgemalde Campaniens_; Helbig, _Untersuchungen uber die</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1353" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1353"></td>
        <td id="LC1353" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     Campanische Wandmalerei_; Mau, _Geschichte der Decorativen</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1354" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1354"></td>
        <td id="LC1354" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     Wandmalerei in Pompeii_; Martha, _L&#39;Archeologie Etrusque et</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1355" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1355"></td>
        <td id="LC1355" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     Romaine_.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1356" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1356"></td>
        <td id="LC1356" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1357" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1357"></td>
        <td id="LC1357" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1358" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1358"></td>
        <td id="LC1358" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">ETRUSCAN PAINTING: Painting in Etruria has not a great deal of</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1359" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1359"></td>
        <td id="LC1359" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">interest for us just here. It was largely decorative and sepulchral in</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1360" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1360"></td>
        <td id="LC1360" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">motive, and was employed in the painting of tombs, and upon vases and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1361" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1361"></td>
        <td id="LC1361" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">other objects placed in the tombs. It had a native way of expressing</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1362" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1362"></td>
        <td id="LC1362" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">itself, which at first was neither Greek nor Oriental, and yet a</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1363" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1363"></td>
        <td id="LC1363" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">reminder of both. Technically it was not well done. Before 500 B.C. it</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1364" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1364"></td>
        <td id="LC1364" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">was almost childish in the drawing. After that date the figures were</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1365" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1365"></td>
        <td id="LC1365" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">better, though short and squat. Those on the vases usually show</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1366" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1366"></td>
        <td id="LC1366" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">outline drawing filled in with dull browns and yellows. Finally there</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1367" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1367"></td>
        <td id="LC1367" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">was a mingling of Etruscan with Greek elements, and an imitation of</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1368" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1368"></td>
        <td id="LC1368" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Greek methods. It was at best a hybrid art, but of some importance</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1369" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1369"></td>
        <td id="LC1369" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">from an archaeological point of view.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1370" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1370"></td>
        <td id="LC1370" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1371" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1371"></td>
        <td id="LC1371" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">ROMAN PAINTING: Roman art is an appendix to the art history of Greece.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1372" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1372"></td>
        <td id="LC1372" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">It originated little in painting, and was content to perpetuate the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1373" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1373"></td>
        <td id="LC1373" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">traditions of Greece in an imitative way. What was worse, it copied</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1374" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1374"></td>
        <td id="LC1374" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">the degeneracy of Greece by following the degenerate Hellenistic</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1375" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1375"></td>
        <td id="LC1375" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">paintings. In motive and method it was substantially the same work as</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1376" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1376"></td>
        <td id="LC1376" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">that of the Greeks under the Diadochi. The subjects, again, were often</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1377" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1377"></td>
        <td id="LC1377" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">taken from Greek story, though there were Roman historical scenes,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1378" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1378"></td>
        <td id="LC1378" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">_genre_ pieces, and many portraits.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1379" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1379"></td>
        <td id="LC1379" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1380" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1380"></td>
        <td id="LC1380" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">[Illustration: FIG. 15.--RITUAL SCENE, PALATINE WALL PAINTING. (FROM</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1381" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1381"></td>
        <td id="LC1381" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">WOLTMANN AND WOERMANN.)]</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1382" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1382"></td>
        <td id="LC1382" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1383" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1383"></td>
        <td id="LC1383" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">In the beginning of the Empire tablet or panel painting was rather</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1384" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1384"></td>
        <td id="LC1384" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">abandoned in favor of mural decoration. That is to say, figures or</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1385" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1385"></td>
        <td id="LC1385" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">groups were painted in fresco on the wall and then surrounded by</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1386" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1386"></td>
        <td id="LC1386" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">geometrical, floral, or architectural designs to give the effect of a</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1387" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1387"></td>
        <td id="LC1387" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">panel let into the wall. Thus painting assumed a more decorative</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1388" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1388"></td>
        <td id="LC1388" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">nature. Vitruvius says in effect that in the early days nature was</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1389" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1389"></td>
        <td id="LC1389" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">followed in these wall paintings, but later on they became ornate and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1390" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1390"></td>
        <td id="LC1390" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">overdone, showing many unsupported architectural facades and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1391" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1391"></td>
        <td id="LC1391" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">impossible decorative framings. This can be traced in the Roman and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1392" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1392"></td>
        <td id="LC1392" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Pompeian frescos. There were four kinds of these wall paintings. (1.)</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1393" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1393"></td>
        <td id="LC1393" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Those that covered all the walls of a room and did away with dado,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1394" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1394"></td>
        <td id="LC1394" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">frieze, and the like, such as figures with large landscape</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1395" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1395"></td>
        <td id="LC1395" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">backgrounds showing villas and trees. (2.) Small paintings separated</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1396" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1396"></td>
        <td id="LC1396" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">or framed by pilasters. (3.) Panel pictures let into the wall or</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1397" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1397"></td>
        <td id="LC1397" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">painted with that effect. (4.) Single figures with architectural</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1398" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1398"></td>
        <td id="LC1398" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">backgrounds. The single figures were usually the best. They had grace</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1399" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1399"></td>
        <td id="LC1399" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">of line and motion and all the truth to nature that decoration</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1400" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1400"></td>
        <td id="LC1400" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">required. Some of the backgrounds were flat tints of red or black</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1401" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1401"></td>
        <td id="LC1401" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">against which the figure was placed. In the larger pieces the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L1402" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="1402"></td>
