        <td id="LC5070" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5071" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5071"></td>
        <td id="LC5071" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">[Illustration: FIG. 68.--MEISSONIER. NAPOLEON IN 1814.]</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5072" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5072"></td>
        <td id="LC5072" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5073" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5073"></td>
        <td id="LC5073" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">THE IMPRESSIONISTS: The name is a misnomer. Every painter is an</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5074" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5074"></td>
        <td id="LC5074" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">impressionist in so far as he records his impressions, and all art is</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5075" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5075"></td>
        <td id="LC5075" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">impressionistic. What Manet (1833-1883), the leader of the original</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5076" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5076"></td>
        <td id="LC5076" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">movement, meant to say was that nature should not be painted as it</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5077" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5077"></td>
        <td id="LC5077" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">actually is, but as it &quot;impresses&quot; the painter. He and his few</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5078" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5078"></td>
        <td id="LC5078" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">followers tried to change the name to Independents, but the original</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5079" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5079"></td>
        <td id="LC5079" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">name has clung to them and been mistakenly fastened to a present band</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5080" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5080"></td>
        <td id="LC5080" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">of landscape painters who are seeking effects of light and air and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5081" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5081"></td>
        <td id="LC5081" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">should be called luminists if it is necessary for them to be named at</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5082" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5082"></td>
        <td id="LC5082" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">all. Manet was extravagant in method and disposed toward low life for</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5083" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5083"></td>
        <td id="LC5083" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">a subject, which has always militated against his popularity; but he</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5084" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5084"></td>
        <td id="LC5084" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">was a very important man for his technical discoveries regarding the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5085" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5085"></td>
        <td id="LC5085" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">relations of light and shadow, the flat appearance of nature, the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5086" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5086"></td>
        <td id="LC5086" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">exact value of color tones. Some of his works, like The Boy with a</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5087" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5087"></td>
        <td id="LC5087" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Sword and The Toreador Dead, are excellent pieces of painting. The</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5088" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5088"></td>
        <td id="LC5088" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">higher imaginative qualities of art Manet made no great effort at</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5089" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5089"></td>
        <td id="LC5089" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">attaining.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5090" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5090"></td>
        <td id="LC5090" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5091" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5091"></td>
        <td id="LC5091" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Degas stands quite by himself, strong in effects of motion, especially</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5092" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5092"></td>
        <td id="LC5092" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">with race-horses, fine in color, and a delightful brushman in such</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5093" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5093"></td>
        <td id="LC5093" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">subjects as ballet-girls and scenes from the theatre. Besnard is one</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5094" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5094"></td>
        <td id="LC5094" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">of the best of the present men. He deals with the figure, and is</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5095" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5095"></td>
        <td id="LC5095" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">usually concerned with the problem of harmonizing color under</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5096" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5096"></td>
        <td id="LC5096" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">conflicting lights, such as twilight and lamplight. Beraud and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5097" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5097"></td>
        <td id="LC5097" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Raffaelli are exceedingly clever in street scenes and character</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5098" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5098"></td>
        <td id="LC5098" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">pieces; Pissarro[16] handles the peasantry in high color; Brown</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5099" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5099"></td>
        <td id="LC5099" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">(1829-1890), the race-horse, and Renoir, the middle class of social</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5100" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5100"></td>
        <td id="LC5100" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">life. Caillebotte, Roll, Forain, and Miss Cassatt, an American, are</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5101" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5101"></td>
        <td id="LC5101" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">also classed with the impressionists.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5102" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5102"></td>
        <td id="LC5102" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5103" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5103"></td>
        <td id="LC5103" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">[Footnote 16: Died, 1903.]</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5104" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5104"></td>
        <td id="LC5104" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5105" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5105"></td>
        <td id="LC5105" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">IMPRESSIONIST LANDSCAPE PAINTERS: Of recent years there has been a</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5106" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5106"></td>
        <td id="LC5106" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">disposition to change the key of light in landscape painting, to get</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5107" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5107"></td>
        <td id="LC5107" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">nearer the truth of nature in the height of light and in the height of</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5108" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5108"></td>
        <td id="LC5108" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">shadows. In doing this Claude Monet, the present leader of the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5109" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5109"></td>
        <td id="LC5109" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">movement, has done away with the dark brown or black shadow and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5110" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5110"></td>
        <td id="LC5110" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">substituted the light-colored shadow, which is nearer the actual truth</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5111" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5111"></td>
        <td id="LC5111" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">of nature. In trying to raise the pitch of light he has not been quite</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5112" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5112"></td>
        <td id="LC5112" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">so successful, though accomplishing something. His method is to use</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5113" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5113"></td>
        <td id="LC5113" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">pure prismatic colors on the principle that color is light in a</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5114" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5114"></td>
        <td id="LC5114" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">decomposed form, and that its proper juxtaposition on canvas will</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5115" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5115"></td>
        <td id="LC5115" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">recompose into pure light again. Hence the use of light shadows and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5116" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5116"></td>
        <td id="LC5116" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">bright colors. The aim of these modern men is chiefly to gain the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5117" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5117"></td>
        <td id="LC5117" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">effect of light and air. They do not apparently care for subject,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5118" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5118"></td>
        <td id="LC5118" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">detail, or composition.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5119" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5119"></td>
        <td id="LC5119" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5120" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5120"></td>
        <td id="LC5120" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">At present their work is in the experimental stage, but from the way</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5121" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5121"></td>
        <td id="LC5121" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">in which it is being accepted and followed by the painters of to-day</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5122" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5122"></td>
        <td id="LC5122" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">we may be sure the movement is of considerable importance. There will</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5123" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5123"></td>
        <td id="LC5123" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">probably be a reaction  in favor of more form and solidity than the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5124" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5124"></td>
        <td id="LC5124" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">present men give, but the high key of light will be retained. There</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5125" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5125"></td>
        <td id="LC5125" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">are so many painters following these modern methods, not only in</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5126" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5126"></td>
        <td id="LC5126" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">France but all over the world, that a list of their names would be</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5127" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5127"></td>
        <td id="LC5127" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">impossible. In France Sisley with Monet are the two important</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5128" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5128"></td>
        <td id="LC5128" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">landscapists. In marines Boudin and Montenard should be mentioned.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5129" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5129"></td>
        <td id="LC5129" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5130" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5130"></td>
        <td id="LC5130" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     PRINCIPAL WORKS: The modern French painters are seen to</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5131" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5131"></td>

        <td id="LC5146" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     BOOKS RECOMMENDED: Bermudez, _Diccionario de las Bellas</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5147" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5147"></td>
        <td id="LC5147" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     Artes en Espana_; Davillier, _Memoire de Velasquez_;</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5148" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5148"></td>
        <td id="LC5148" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     Davillier, _Fortuny_; Eusebi, _Los Differentes Escuelas de</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5149" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5149"></td>
        <td id="LC5149" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     Pintura_; Ford, _Handbook of Spain_; Head, _History of</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5150" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5150"></td>

        <td id="L5151" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5151"></td>

        <td id="L5153" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5153"></td>

      <tr>
        <td id="L5154" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5154"></td>

        <td id="L5155" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5155"></td>

      <tr>
        <td id="L5161" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5161"></td>
        <td id="LC5161" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     _Goya, sa Biographie_, etc.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5162" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5162"></td>
        <td id="LC5162" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5163" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5163"></td>
        <td id="LC5163" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5164" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5164"></td>
        <td id="LC5164" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">SPANISH ART MOTIVES: What may have been the early art of Spain we are</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5165" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5165"></td>
        <td id="LC5165" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">at a loss to conjecture. The reigns of the Moor, the Iconoclast, and,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5166" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5166"></td>
        <td id="LC5166" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">finally, the Inquisitor, have left little that dates before the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5167" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5167"></td>
        <td id="LC5167" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">fourteenth century. The miniatures and sacred relics treasured in the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5168" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5168"></td>
        <td id="LC5168" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">churches and said to be of the apostolic period, show the traces of a</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5169" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5169"></td>
        <td id="LC5169" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">much later date and a foreign origin. Even when we come down to the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5170" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5170"></td>
        <td id="LC5170" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">fifteenth century and meet with art produced in Spain, we have a</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5171" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5171"></td>
        <td id="LC5171" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">following of Italy or the Netherlands. In methods and technic it was</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5172" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5172"></td>
        <td id="LC5172" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">derivative more than original, though almost from the beginning</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5173" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5173"></td>
        <td id="LC5173" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">peculiarly Spanish in spirit.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5174" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5174"></td>
        <td id="LC5174" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5175" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5175"></td>
        <td id="LC5175" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">[Illustration: FIG. 69.--SANCHEZ COELLO. CLARA EUGENIA, DAUGHTER OF</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5176" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5176"></td>
        <td id="LC5176" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">PHILIP II. MADRID.]</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5177" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5177"></td>
        <td id="LC5177" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5178" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5178"></td>
        <td id="LC5178" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">That spirit was a dark and savage one, a something that cringed under</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5179" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5179"></td>
        <td id="LC5179" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">the lash of the Church, bowed before the Inquisition, and played the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5180" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5180"></td>
        <td id="LC5180" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">executioner with the paint-brush. The bulk of Spanish art was Church</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5181" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5181"></td>
        <td id="LC5181" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">art, done under ecclesiastical domination, and done in form without</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5182" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5182"></td>
        <td id="LC5182" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">question or protest. The religious subject ruled. True enough, there</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5183" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5183"></td>
        <td id="LC5183" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">was portraiture of nobility, and under Philip and Velasquez a</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5184" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5184"></td>
        <td id="LC5184" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">half-monarchical art of military scenes and _genre_; but this was not</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5185" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5185"></td>
        <td id="LC5185" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">the bent of Spanish painting as a whole. Even in late days, when</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5186" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5186"></td>
        <td id="LC5186" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Velasquez was reflecting the haughty court, Murillo was more widely</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5187" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5187"></td>
        <td id="LC5187" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">and nationally reflecting the believing provinces and the Church</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5188" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5188"></td>
        <td id="LC5188" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">faith of the people. It is safe to say, in a general way, that the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5189" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5189"></td>
        <td id="LC5189" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Church was responsible for Spanish art, and that religion was its</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5190" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5190"></td>
        <td id="LC5190" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">chief motive.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5191" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5191"></td>
        <td id="LC5191" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5192" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5192"></td>
        <td id="LC5192" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">There was no revived antique, little of the nude or the pagan, little</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5193" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5193"></td>
        <td id="LC5193" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">of consequence in landscape, little, until Velasquez&#39;s time, of the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5194" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5194"></td>
        <td id="LC5194" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">real and the actual. An ascetic view of life, faith, and the hereafter</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5195" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5195"></td>
        <td id="LC5195" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">prevailed. The pietistic, the fervent, and the devout were not so</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5196" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5196"></td>
        <td id="LC5196" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">conspicuous as the morose, the ghastly, and the horrible. The saints</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5197" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5197"></td>
        <td id="LC5197" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">and martyrs, the crucifixions and violent deaths, were eloquent of the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5198" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5198"></td>
        <td id="LC5198" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">torture-chamber. It was more ecclesiasticism by blood and violence</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5199" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5199"></td>
        <td id="LC5199" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">than Christianity by peace and love. And Spain welcomed this. For of</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5200" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5200"></td>
        <td id="LC5200" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">all the children of the Church she was the most faithful to rule,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5201" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5201"></td>
        <td id="LC5201" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">crushing out heresy with an iron hand, gaining strength from the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5202" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5202"></td>
        <td id="LC5202" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Catholic reaction, and upholding the Jesuits and the Inquisition.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5203" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5203"></td>
        <td id="LC5203" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5204" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5204"></td>
        <td id="LC5204" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">METHODS OF PAINTING: Spanish art worthy of mention did not appear</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5205" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5205"></td>
        <td id="LC5205" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">until the fifteenth century. At that time Spain was in close relations</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5206" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5206"></td>
        <td id="LC5206" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">with the Netherlands, and Flemish painting was somewhat followed. How</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5207" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5207"></td>
        <td id="LC5207" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">much the methods of the Van Eycks influenced Spain would be hard to</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5208" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5208"></td>
        <td id="LC5208" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">determine, especially as these Northern methods were mixed with</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5209" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5209"></td>
        <td id="LC5209" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">influences coming from Italy. Finally, the Italian example prevailed</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5210" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5210"></td>
        <td id="LC5210" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">by reason of Spanish students in Italy and Italian painters in Spain.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5211" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5211"></td>
        <td id="LC5211" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Florentine line, Venetian color, and Neapolitan light-and-shade ruled</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5212" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5212"></td>
        <td id="LC5212" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">almost everywhere, and it was not until the time of Velasquez--the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5213" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5213"></td>
        <td id="LC5213" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">period just before the eighteenth-century decline--that distinctly</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5214" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5214"></td>
        <td id="LC5214" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Spanish methods, founded on nature, really came forcibly to the front.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5215" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5215"></td>
        <td id="LC5215" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5216" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5216"></td>
        <td id="LC5216" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">SPANISH SCHOOLS OF PAINTING: There is difficulty in classifying these</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5217" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5217"></td>
        <td id="LC5217" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">schools of painting because our present knowledge of them is limited.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5218" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5218"></td>
        <td id="LC5218" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Isolated somewhat from the rest of Europe, the Spanish painters have</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5219" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5219"></td>
        <td id="LC5219" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">never been critically studied as the Italians have been, and what is</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5220" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5220"></td>
        <td id="LC5220" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">at present known about the schools must be accepted subject to</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5221" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5221"></td>
        <td id="LC5221" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">critical revision hereafter.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5222" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5222"></td>
        <td id="LC5222" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5223" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5223"></td>
        <td id="LC5223" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">[Illustration: FIG. 70.--MURILLO. ST. ANTHONY OF PADUA. BERLIN.]</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5224" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5224"></td>
        <td id="LC5224" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5225" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5225"></td>
        <td id="LC5225" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">The earliest school seems to have been made up from a gathering of</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5226" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5226"></td>
        <td id="LC5226" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">artists at Toledo, who limned, carved, and gilded in the cathedral;</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5227" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5227"></td>
        <td id="LC5227" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">but this school was not of long duration. It was merged into the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5228" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5228"></td>
        <td id="LC5228" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Castilian school, which, after the building of Madrid, made its home</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5229" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5229"></td>
        <td id="LC5229" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">in that capital and drew its forces from the towns of Toledo,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5230" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5230"></td>
        <td id="LC5230" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Valladolid, and Badajoz. The Andalusian school, which rose about the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5231" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5231"></td>
        <td id="LC5231" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">middle of the sixteenth century, was made up from the local schools of</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5232" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5232"></td>
        <td id="LC5232" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Seville, Cordova, and Granada. The Valencian school, to the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5233" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5233"></td>
        <td id="LC5233" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">southeast, rose about the same time, and was finally merged into the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5234" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5234"></td>
        <td id="LC5234" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Andalusian. The Aragonese school, to the east, was small and of no</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5235" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5235"></td>
        <td id="LC5235" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">great consequence, though existing in a feeble way to the end of the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5236" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5236"></td>
        <td id="LC5236" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">seventeenth century. The painters of these schools are not very</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5237" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5237"></td>
        <td id="LC5237" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">strongly marked apart by methods or school traditions, and perhaps the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5238" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5238"></td>
        <td id="LC5238" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">divisions would better be looked upon as more geographical than</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5239" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5239"></td>
        <td id="LC5239" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">otherwise. None of the schools really began before the sixteenth</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5240" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5240"></td>
        <td id="LC5240" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">century, though there are names of artists and some extant pictures</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5241" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5241"></td>
        <td id="LC5241" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">before that date, and with the seventeenth century all art in Spain</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5242" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5242"></td>
        <td id="LC5242" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">seems to have centred about Madrid.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5243" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5243"></td>
        <td id="LC5243" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5244" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5244"></td>
        <td id="LC5244" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Spanish painting started into life concurrently with the rise to</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5245" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5245"></td>
        <td id="LC5245" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">prominence of Spain as a political kingdom. What, if any, direct</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5246" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5246"></td>
        <td id="LC5246" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">effect the maritime discoveries, the conquests of Granada and Naples,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5247" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5247"></td>
        <td id="LC5247" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">the growth of literature, and the decline of Italy, may have had upon</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5248" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5248"></td>
        <td id="LC5248" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Spanish painting can only be conjectured; but certainly the sudden</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5249" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5249"></td>
        <td id="LC5249" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">advance of the nation politically and socially was paralleled by the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5250" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5250"></td>
        <td id="LC5250" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">advance of its art.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5251" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5251"></td>
        <td id="LC5251" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5252" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5252"></td>
        <td id="LC5252" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">THE CASTILIAN SCHOOL: This school probably had no so-called founder.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5253" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5253"></td>
        <td id="LC5253" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">It was a growth from early art traditions at Toledo, and afterward</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5254" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5254"></td>
        <td id="LC5254" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">became the chief school of the kingdom owing to the patronage of</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5255" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5255"></td>
        <td id="LC5255" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Philip II. and Philip IV. at Madrid. The first painter of importance</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5256" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5256"></td>
        <td id="LC5256" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">in the school seems to have been Antonio Rincon (1446?-1500?). He is</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5257" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5257"></td>
        <td id="LC5257" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">sometimes spoken of as the father of Spanish painting, and as having</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5258" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5258"></td>
        <td id="LC5258" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">studied in Italy with Castagno and Ghirlandajo, but there is little</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5259" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5259"></td>
        <td id="LC5259" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">foundation for either statement. He painted chiefly at Toledo, painted</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5260" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5260"></td>
        <td id="LC5260" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">portraits of Ferdinand and Isabella, and had some skill in hard</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5261" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5261"></td>
        <td id="LC5261" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">drawing. Berruguete (1480?-1561) studied with Michael Angelo, and is</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5262" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5262"></td>
        <td id="LC5262" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">supposed to have helped him in the Vatican. He afterward returned to</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5263" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5263"></td>
        <td id="LC5263" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Spain, painted many altar-pieces, and was patronized as painter,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5264" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5264"></td>
        <td id="LC5264" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">sculptor, and architect by Charles V. and Philip II. He was probably</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5265" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5265"></td>
        <td id="LC5265" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">the first to introduce pure Italian methods into Spain, with some</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5266" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5266"></td>
        <td id="LC5266" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">coldness and dryness of coloring and handling. Becerra (1520?-1570)</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5267" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5267"></td>
        <td id="LC5267" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">was born in Andalusia, but worked in Castile, and was a man of Italian</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5268" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5268"></td>
        <td id="LC5268" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">training similar to Berruguete. He was an exceptional man, perhaps, in</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5269" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5269"></td>
        <td id="LC5269" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">his use of mythological themes and nude figures.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5270" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5270"></td>
        <td id="LC5270" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5271" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5271"></td>
        <td id="LC5271" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">There is not a great deal known about Morales (1509?-1586), called</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5272" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5272"></td>
        <td id="LC5272" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">&quot;the Divine,&quot; except that he was allied to the Castilian school, and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5273" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5273"></td>
        <td id="LC5273" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">painted devotional heads of Christ with the crown of thorns, and many</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5274" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5274"></td>
        <td id="LC5274" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">afflicted and weeping madonnas. There was Florentine drawing in his</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5275" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5275"></td>
        <td id="LC5275" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">work, great regard for finish, and something of Correggio&#39;s softness</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5276" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5276"></td>
        <td id="LC5276" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">in shadows pitched in a browner key. His sentiment was rather</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5277" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5277"></td>
        <td id="LC5277" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">exaggerated. Sanchez-Coello (1513?-1590) was painter and courtier to</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5278" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5278"></td>
        <td id="LC5278" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Philip II., and achieved reputation as a portrait-painter, though also</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5279" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5279"></td>
        <td id="LC5279" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">doing some altar-pieces. It is doubtful whether he ever studied in</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5280" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5280"></td>
        <td id="LC5280" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Italy, but in Spain he was for a time with Antonio Moro, and probably</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5281" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5281"></td>
        <td id="LC5281" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">learned from him something of rich costumes, ermines, embroideries,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5282" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5282"></td>
        <td id="LC5282" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">and jewels, for which his portraits were remarkable. Navarette</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5283" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5283"></td>
        <td id="LC5283" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">(1526?-1579), called &quot;El Mudo&quot; (the dumb one), certainly was in Italy</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5284" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5284"></td>
        <td id="LC5284" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">for something like twenty years, and was there a disciple of Titian,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5285" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5285"></td>
        <td id="LC5285" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">from whom he doubtless learned much of color and the free flow of</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5286" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5286"></td>
        <td id="LC5286" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">draperies. He was one of the best of the middle-period painters.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5287" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5287"></td>
        <td id="LC5287" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Theotocopuli (1548?-1625), called &quot;El Greco&quot; (the Greek), was another</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5288" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5288"></td>
        <td id="LC5288" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Venetian-influenced painter, with enough Spanish originality about him</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5289" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5289"></td>
        <td id="LC5289" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">to make most of his pictures striking in color and drawing. Tristan</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5290" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5290"></td>
        <td id="LC5290" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">(1586-1640) was his best follower.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5291" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5291"></td>
        <td id="LC5291" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5292" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5292"></td>
        <td id="LC5292" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">[Illustration: FIG. 71.--RIBERA. ST. AGNES. DRESDEN.]</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5293" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5293"></td>
        <td id="LC5293" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5294" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5294"></td>
        <td id="LC5294" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Velasquez (1599-1660) is the greatest name in the history of Spanish</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5295" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5295"></td>
        <td id="LC5295" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">painting. With him Spanish art took upon itself a decidedly</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5296" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5296"></td>
        <td id="LC5296" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">naturalistic and national stamp. Before his time Italy had been freely</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5297" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5297"></td>
        <td id="LC5297" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">imitated; but though Velasquez himself was in Italy for quite a long</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5298" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5298"></td>
        <td id="LC5298" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">time, and intimately acquainted with great Italian art, he never</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5299" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5299"></td>
        <td id="LC5299" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">seemed to have been led away from his own individual way of seeing and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5300" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5300"></td>
        <td id="LC5300" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">doing. He was a pupil of Herrera, afterward with Pacheco, and learned</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5301" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5301"></td>
        <td id="LC5301" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">much from Ribera and Tristan, but more from a direct study of nature</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5302" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5302"></td>
        <td id="LC5302" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">than from all the others. He was in a broad sense a realist--a man who</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5303" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5303"></td>
        <td id="LC5303" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">recorded the material and the actual without emendation or</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5304" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5304"></td>
        <td id="LC5304" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">transposition. He has never been surpassed in giving the solidity and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5305" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5305"></td>
        <td id="LC5305" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">substance of form and the placing of objects in atmosphere. And this,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5306" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5306"></td>
        <td id="LC5306" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">not in a small, finical way, but with a breadth of view and of</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5307" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5307"></td>
        <td id="LC5307" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">treatment which are to-day the despair of painters. There was nothing</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5308" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5308"></td>
        <td id="LC5308" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">of the ethereal, the spiritual, the pietistic, or the pathetic about</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5309" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5309"></td>
        <td id="LC5309" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">him. He never for a moment left the firm basis of reality. Standing</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5310" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5310"></td>
        <td id="LC5310" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">upon earth he recorded the truths of the earth, but in their largest,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5311" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5311"></td>
        <td id="LC5311" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">fullest, most universal forms.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5312" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5312"></td>
        <td id="LC5312" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5313" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5313"></td>
        <td id="LC5313" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Technically his was a master-hand, doing all things with ease, giving</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5314" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5314"></td>
        <td id="LC5314" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">exact relations of colors and lights, and placing everything so</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5315" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5315"></td>
        <td id="LC5315" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">perfectly that no addition or alteration is thought of. With the brush</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5316" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5316"></td>
        <td id="LC5316" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">he was light, easy, sure. The surface looks as though touched once, no</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5317" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5317"></td>
        <td id="LC5317" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">more. It is the perfection of handling through its simplicity and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5318" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5318"></td>
        <td id="LC5318" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">certainty, and has not the slightest trace of affectation or</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5319" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5319"></td>
        <td id="LC5319" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">mannerism. He was one of the few Spanish painters who were enabled to</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5320" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5320"></td>
        <td id="LC5320" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">shake off the yoke of the Church. Few of his canvases are religious in</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5321" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5321"></td>
        <td id="LC5321" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">subject. Under royal patronage he passed almost all of his life in</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5322" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5322"></td>
        <td id="LC5322" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">painting portraits of the royal family, ministers of state, and great</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5323" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5323"></td>
        <td id="LC5323" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">dignitaries. As a portrait-painter he is more widely known than as a</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5324" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5324"></td>
        <td id="LC5324" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">figure-painter. Nevertheless he did many canvases like The Tapestry</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5325" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5325"></td>
        <td id="LC5325" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Weavers and The Surrender at Breda, which attest his remarkable genius</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5326" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5326"></td>
        <td id="LC5326" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">in that field; and even in landscape, in _genre_, in animal painting,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5327" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5327"></td>
        <td id="LC5327" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">he was a very superior man. In fact Velasquez is one of the few great</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5328" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5328"></td>
        <td id="LC5328" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">painters in European history for whom there is nothing but praise. He</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5329" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5329"></td>
        <td id="LC5329" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">was the full-rounded complete painter, intensely individual and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5330" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5330"></td>
        <td id="LC5330" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">self-assertive, and yet in his art recording in a broad way the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5331" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5331"></td>
        <td id="LC5331" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Spanish type and life. He was the climax of Spanish painting, and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5332" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5332"></td>
        <td id="LC5332" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">after him there was a rather swift decline, as had been the case in</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5333" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5333"></td>
        <td id="LC5333" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">the Italian schools.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5334" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5334"></td>
        <td id="LC5334" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5335" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5335"></td>
        <td id="LC5335" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Mazo (1610?-1667), pupil and son-in-law of Velasquez, was one of his</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5336" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5336"></td>
        <td id="LC5336" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">most facile imitators, and Carreno de Miranda (1614-1685) was</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5337" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5337"></td>
        <td id="LC5337" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">influenced by Velasquez, and for a time his assistant. The Castilian</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5338" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5338"></td>
        <td id="LC5338" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">school may be said to have closed with these late men and with Claudio</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5339" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5339"></td>
        <td id="LC5339" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Coello (1635?-1693), a painter with a style founded on Titian and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5340" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5340"></td>
        <td id="LC5340" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Rubens, whose best work was of extraordinary power. Spanish painting</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5341" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5341"></td>
        <td id="LC5341" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">went out with Spanish power, and only isolated men of small rank</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5342" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5342"></td>
        <td id="LC5342" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">remained.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5343" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5343"></td>
        <td id="LC5343" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5344" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5344"></td>
        <td id="LC5344" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">ANDALUSIAN SCHOOL: This school came into existence about the middle of</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5345" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5345"></td>
        <td id="LC5345" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">the sixteenth century. Its chief centre was at Seville, and its chief</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5346" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5346"></td>
        <td id="LC5346" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">patron the Church rather than the king. Vargas (1502-1568) was</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5347" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5347"></td>
        <td id="LC5347" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">probably the real founder of the school, though De Castro (fl. 1454)</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5348" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5348"></td>
        <td id="LC5348" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">and others preceded him. Vargas was a man of much reputation and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5349" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5349"></td>
        <td id="LC5349" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">ability in his time, and introduced Italian methods and elegance into</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5350" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5350"></td>
        <td id="LC5350" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">the Andalusian school after twenty odd years of residence in Italy. He</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5351" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5351"></td>
        <td id="LC5351" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">is said to have studied under Perino del Vaga, and there is some</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5352" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5352"></td>
        <td id="LC5352" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">sweetness of face and grace of form about his work that point that</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5353" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5353"></td>
        <td id="LC5353" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">way, though his composition suggests Correggio. Most of his frescos</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5354" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5354"></td>
        <td id="LC5354" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">have perished; some of his canvases are still in existence.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5355" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5355"></td>
        <td id="LC5355" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5356" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5356"></td>
        <td id="LC5356" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Cespedes (1538?-1608) is little known through extant works, but he</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5357" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5357"></td>
        <td id="LC5357" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">achieved fame in many departments during his life, and is said to have</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5358" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5358"></td>
        <td id="LC5358" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">been in Italy under Florentine influence. His coloring was rather</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5359" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5359"></td>
        <td id="LC5359" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">cold, and his drawing large and flat. The best early painter of the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5360" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5360"></td>
        <td id="LC5360" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">school was Roelas (1558?-1625), the inspirer of Murillo and the master</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5361" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5361"></td>
        <td id="LC5361" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">of Zurbaran. He is supposed to have studied at Venice, because of his</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5362" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5362"></td>
        <td id="LC5362" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">rich, glowing color. Most of his works are religious and are found</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5363" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5363"></td>
        <td id="LC5363" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">chiefly at Seville. He was greatly patronized by the Jesuits. Pacheco</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5364" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5364"></td>
        <td id="LC5364" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">(1571-1654) was more of a pedant than a painter, a man of rule, who</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5365" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5365"></td>
        <td id="LC5365" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">to-day might be written down an academician. His drawing was hard, and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5366" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5366"></td>
        <td id="LC5366" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">perhaps the best reason for his being remembered is that he was one of</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5367" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5367"></td>
        <td id="LC5367" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">the masters and the father-in-law of Velasquez. His rival, Herrera the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5368" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5368"></td>
        <td id="LC5368" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Elder (1576?-1656) was a stronger man--in fact, the most original</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5369" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5369"></td>
        <td id="LC5369" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">artist of his school. He struck off by himself and created a bold</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5370" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5370"></td>
        <td id="LC5370" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">realism with a broad brush that anticipated Velasquez--in fact,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5371" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5371"></td>
        <td id="LC5371" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Velasquez was under him for a time.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5372" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5372"></td>
        <td id="LC5372" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5373" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5373"></td>
        <td id="LC5373" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">The pure Spanish school in Andalusia, as distinct from Italian</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5374" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5374"></td>
        <td id="LC5374" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">imitation, may be said to have started with Herrera. It was further</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5375" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5375"></td>
        <td id="LC5375" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">advanced by another independent painter, Zurbaran (1598-1662), a pupil</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5376" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5376"></td>
        <td id="LC5376" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">of Roelas. He was a painter of the emaciated monk in ecstasy, and many</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5377" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5377"></td>
        <td id="LC5377" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">other rather dismal religious subjects expressive of tortured rapture.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5378" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5378"></td>
        <td id="LC5378" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">From using a rather dark shadow he acquired the name of the Spanish</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5379" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5379"></td>
        <td id="LC5379" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Caravaggio. He had a good deal of Caravaggio&#39;s strength, together with</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5380" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5380"></td>
        <td id="LC5380" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">a depth and breadth of color suggestive of the Venetians. Cano</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5381" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5381"></td>
        <td id="LC5381" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">(1601-1667), though he never was in Italy, had the name of the Spanish</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5382" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5382"></td>
        <td id="LC5382" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Michael Angelo, probably because he was sculptor, painter, and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5383" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5383"></td>
        <td id="LC5383" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">architect. His painting was rather sharp in line and statuesque in</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5384" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5384"></td>
        <td id="LC5384" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">pose, with a coloring somewhat like that of Van Dyck. It was eclectic</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5385" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5385"></td>
        <td id="LC5385" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">rather than original work.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5386" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5386"></td>
        <td id="LC5386" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5387" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5387"></td>
        <td id="LC5387" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">[Illustration: FIG. 72.--FORTUNY. SPANISH MARRIAGE.]</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5388" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5388"></td>
        <td id="LC5388" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5389" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5389"></td>
        <td id="LC5389" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Murillo (1618-1682) is generally placed at the head of the Andalusian</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5390" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5390"></td>
        <td id="LC5390" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">school, as Velasquez at the head of the Castilian. There is good</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5391" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5391"></td>
        <td id="LC5391" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">reason for it, for though Murillo was not the great painter he was</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5392" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5392"></td>
        <td id="LC5392" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">sometime supposed, yet he was not the weak man his modern critics</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5393" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5393"></td>
        <td id="LC5393" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">would make him out. A religious painter largely, though doing some</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5394" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5394"></td>
        <td id="LC5394" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">_genre_ subjects like his beggar-boy groups, he sought for religious</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5395" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5395"></td>
        <td id="LC5395" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">fervor and found, only too often, sentimentality. His madonnas are</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5396" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5396"></td>
        <td id="LC5396" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">usually after the Carlo Dolci pattern, though never so excessive in</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5397" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5397"></td>
        <td id="LC5397" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">sentiment. This was not the case with his earlier works, mostly of</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5398" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5398"></td>
        <td id="LC5398" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">humble life, which were painted in rather a hard, positive manner.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5399" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5399"></td>
        <td id="LC5399" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Later on he became misty, veiled in light and effeminate in outline,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5400" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5400"></td>
        <td id="LC5400" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">though still holding grace. His color varied with his early and later</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5401" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5401"></td>
        <td id="LC5401" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">styles. It was usually gay and a little thin. While basing his work on</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5402" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5402"></td>
        <td id="LC5402" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">nature like Velasquez, he never had the supreme poise of that master,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5403" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5403"></td>
        <td id="LC5403" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">either mentally or technically; howbeit he was an excellent painter,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5404" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5404"></td>
        <td id="LC5404" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">who perhaps justly holds second place in Spanish art.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5405" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5405"></td>
        <td id="LC5405" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5406" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5406"></td>
        <td id="LC5406" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">SCHOOL OF VALENCIA: This school rose contemporary with the Andalusian</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5407" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5407"></td>
        <td id="LC5407" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">school, into which it was finally merged after the importance of</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5408" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5408"></td>
        <td id="LC5408" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Madrid had been established. It was largely modelled upon Italian</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5409" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5409"></td>
        <td id="LC5409" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">painting, as indeed were all the schools of Spain at the start. Juan</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5410" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5410"></td>
        <td id="LC5410" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">de Joanes (1507?-1579) apparently was its founder, a man who painted a</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5411" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5411"></td>
        <td id="LC5411" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">good portrait, but in other respects was only a fair imitator of</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5412" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5412"></td>
        <td id="LC5412" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Raphael, whom he had studied at Rome. A stronger man was Francisco de</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5413" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5413"></td>
        <td id="LC5413" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Ribalta (1550?-1628), who was for a time in Italy under the Caracci,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5414" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5414"></td>
        <td id="LC5414" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">and learned from them free draughtsmanship and elaborate composition.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5415" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5415"></td>
        <td id="LC5415" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">He was also fond of Sebastiano del Piombo, and in his best works (at</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5416" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5416"></td>
        <td id="LC5416" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Valencia) reflected him. Ribalta gave an early training to Ribera</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5417" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5417"></td>
        <td id="LC5417" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">(1588-1656), who was the most important man of this school. In reality</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5418" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5418"></td>
        <td id="LC5418" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Ribera was more Italian than Valencian, for he spent the greater part</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5419" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5419"></td>
        <td id="LC5419" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">of his life in Italy, where he was called Lo Spagnoletto, and was</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5420" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5420"></td>
        <td id="LC5420" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">greatly influenced by Caravaggio. He was a Spaniard in the horrible</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5421" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5421"></td>
