        <td id="LC5763" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">tender feeling. Something of the Paolo Veronese cast of mind, he</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5764" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5764"></td>
        <td id="LC5764" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">conceived things largely, and painted them proportionately--large</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5765" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5765"></td>
        <td id="LC5765" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Titanic types, broad schemes and masses of color, great sweeping lines</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5766" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5766"></td>
        <td id="LC5766" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">of beauty. One value of this largeness was its ability to hold at a</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5767" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5767"></td>
        <td id="LC5767" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">distance upon wall or altar. Hence, when seen to-day, close at hand, in</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5768" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5768"></td>
        <td id="LC5768" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">museums, people are apt to think Rubens&#39;s art coarse and gross.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5769" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5769"></td>
        <td id="LC5769" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5770" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5770"></td>
        <td id="LC5770" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">There is no prettiness about his type. It is not effeminate or</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5771" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5771"></td>
        <td id="LC5771" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">sentimental, but rather robust, full of life and animal spirits, full</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5772" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5772"></td>
        <td id="LC5772" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">of blood, bone, and muscle--of majestic dignity, grace, and power, and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5773" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5773"></td>
        <td id="LC5773" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">glowing with splendor of color. In imagination, in conception of art</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5774" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5774"></td>
        <td id="LC5774" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">purely as art, and not as a mere vehicle to convey religious or</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5775" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5775"></td>
        <td id="LC5775" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">mythological ideas, in mental grasp of the pictorial world, Rubens</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5776" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5776"></td>
        <td id="LC5776" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">stands with Titian and Velasquez in the very front rank of painters.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5777" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5777"></td>
        <td id="LC5777" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">As a technician, he was unexcelled. A master of composition,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5778" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5778"></td>
        <td id="LC5778" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">modelling, and drawing, a master of light, and a color-harmonist of</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5779" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5779"></td>
        <td id="LC5779" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">the rarest ability, he, in addition, possessed the most certain,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5780" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5780"></td>
        <td id="LC5780" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">adroit, and facile hand that ever handled a paint-brush. Nothing could</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5781" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5781"></td>
        <td id="LC5781" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">be more sure than the touch of Rubens, nothing more easy and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5782" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5782"></td>
        <td id="LC5782" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">masterful. He was trained in both mind and eye, a genius by birth and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5783" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5783"></td>
        <td id="LC5783" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">by education, a painter who saw keenly, and was able to realize what</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5784" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5784"></td>
        <td id="LC5784" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">he saw with certainty.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5785" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5785"></td>
        <td id="LC5785" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5786" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5786"></td>
        <td id="LC5786" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Well-born, ennobled by royalty, successful in both court and studio,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5787" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5787"></td>
        <td id="LC5787" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Rubens lived brilliantly and his life was a series of triumphs. He</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5788" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5788"></td>
        <td id="LC5788" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">painted enormous canvases, and the number of pictures, altar-pieces,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5789" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5789"></td>
        <td id="LC5789" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">mythological decorations, landscapes, portraits scattered throughout</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5790" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5790"></td>
        <td id="LC5790" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">the galleries of Europe, and attributed to him, is simply amazing. He</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5791" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5791"></td>
        <td id="LC5791" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">was undoubtedly helped in many of his canvases by his pupils, but the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5792" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5792"></td>
        <td id="LC5792" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">works painted by his own hand make a world of art in themselves. He</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5793" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5793"></td>
        <td id="LC5793" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">was the greatest painter of the North, a full-rounded, complete</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5794" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5794"></td>
        <td id="LC5794" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">genius, comparable to Titian in his universality. His precursors and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5795" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5795"></td>
        <td id="LC5795" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">masters, Van Noort (1562-1641) and Vaenius (1558-1629), gave no strong</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5796" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5796"></td>
        <td id="LC5796" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">indication of the greatness of Ruben&#39;s art, and his many pupils,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5797" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5797"></td>
        <td id="LC5797" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">though echoing his methods, never rose to his height in mental or</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5798" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5798"></td>
        <td id="LC5798" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">artistic grasp.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5799" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5799"></td>
        <td id="LC5799" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5800" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5800"></td>
        <td id="LC5800" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">[Illustration: FIG. 78.--VAN DYCK. PORTRAIT OF CORNELIUS VAN DER</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5801" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5801"></td>
        <td id="LC5801" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">GEEST. NAT. GAL. LONDON.]</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5802" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5802"></td>
        <td id="LC5802" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5803" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5803"></td>
        <td id="LC5803" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Van Dyck (1599-1641) was his principal pupil. He followed Rubens</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5804" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5804"></td>
        <td id="LC5804" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">closely at first, though in a slighter manner technically, and with a</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5805" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5805"></td>
        <td id="LC5805" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">cooler coloring. After visiting Italy he took up with the warmth of</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5806" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5806"></td>
        <td id="LC5806" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Titian. Later, in England, he became careless and less certain. His</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5807" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5807"></td>
        <td id="LC5807" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">rank is given him not for his figure-pieces. They were not always</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5808" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5808"></td>
        <td id="LC5808" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">successful, lacking as they did in imagination and originality, though</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5809" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5809"></td>
        <td id="LC5809" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">done with force. His best work was his portraiture, for which he</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5810" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5810"></td>
        <td id="LC5810" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">became famous, painting nobility in every country of Europe in which</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5811" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5811"></td>
        <td id="LC5811" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">he visited. At his best he was a portrait-painter of great power, but</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5812" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5812"></td>
        <td id="LC5812" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">not to be placed in the same rank with Titian, Rubens, Rembrandt, and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5813" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5813"></td>
        <td id="LC5813" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Velasquez. His characters are gracefully posed, and appear to be</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5814" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5814"></td>
        <td id="LC5814" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">aristocratic. There is a noble distinction about them, and yet even</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5815" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5815"></td>
        <td id="LC5815" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">this has the feeling of being somewhat affected. The serene</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5816" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5816"></td>
        <td id="LC5816" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">complacency of his lords and ladies finally became almost a mannerism</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5817" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5817"></td>
        <td id="LC5817" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">with him, though never a disagreeable one. He died early, a painter of</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5818" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5818"></td>
        <td id="LC5818" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">mark, but not the greatest portrait-painter of the world, as is</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5819" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5819"></td>
        <td id="LC5819" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">sometimes said of him.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5820" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5820"></td>
        <td id="LC5820" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5821" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5821"></td>
        <td id="LC5821" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">There were a number of Rubens&#39;s pupils, like Diepenbeeck (1596-1675),</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5822" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5822"></td>
        <td id="LC5822" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">who learned from their master a certain brush facility, but were not</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5823" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5823"></td>
        <td id="LC5823" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">sufficiently original to make deep impressions. When Rubens died the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5824" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5824"></td>
        <td id="LC5824" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">best painter left in Belgium was Jordaens (1593-1678). He was a pupil</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5825" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5825"></td>
        <td id="LC5825" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">of Van Noort, but submitted to the Rubens influence and followed in</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5826" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5826"></td>
        <td id="LC5826" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Rubens&#39;s style, though more florid in coloring and grosser in types.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5827" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5827"></td>
        <td id="LC5827" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">He painted all sorts of subjects, but was seen at his best in</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5828" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5828"></td>
        <td id="LC5828" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">mythological scenes with groups of drunken satyrs and bacchants,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5829" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5829"></td>
        <td id="LC5829" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">surrounded by a close-placed landscape. He was the most independent</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5830" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5830"></td>
        <td id="LC5830" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">and original of the followers, of whom there was a host. Crayer</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5831" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5831"></td>
        <td id="LC5831" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">(1582-1669), Janssens (1575-1632), Zegers (1591-1651), Rombouts</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5832" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5832"></td>
        <td id="LC5832" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">(1597-1637), were the prominent ones. They all took an influence more</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5833" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5833"></td>
        <td id="LC5833" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">or less pronounced from Rubens. Cornelius de Vos (1585-1651) was a</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5834" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5834"></td>
        <td id="LC5834" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">more independent man--a realistic portrait-painter of much ability.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5835" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5835"></td>
        <td id="LC5835" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Snyders (1579-1657), and Fyt (1609?-1661), devoted their brushes to</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5836" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5836"></td>
        <td id="LC5836" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">the painting of still-life, game, fruits, flowers, landscape--Snyders</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5837" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5837"></td>
        <td id="LC5837" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">often in collaboration with Rubens himself.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5838" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5838"></td>
        <td id="LC5838" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5839" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5839"></td>
        <td id="LC5839" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">[Illustration: FIG. 79.--TENIERS THE YOUNGER. PRODIGAL SON. LOUVRE.]</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5840" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5840"></td>
        <td id="LC5840" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5841" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5841"></td>
        <td id="LC5841" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Living at the same time with these half-Italianized painters, and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5842" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5842"></td>
        <td id="LC5842" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">continuing later in the century, there was another group of painters</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5843" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5843"></td>
        <td id="LC5843" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">in the Low Countries who were emphatically of the soil, believing in</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5844" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5844"></td>
        <td id="LC5844" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">themselves and their own country and picturing scenes from commonplace</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5845" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5845"></td>
        <td id="LC5845" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">life in a manner quite their own. These were the &quot;Little Masters,&quot; the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5846" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5846"></td>
        <td id="LC5846" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">_genre_ painters, of whom there was even a stronger representation</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5847" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5847"></td>
        <td id="LC5847" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">appearing contemporaneously in Holland. In Belgium there were not so</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5848" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5848"></td>
        <td id="LC5848" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">many nor such talented men, but some of them were very interesting in</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5849" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5849"></td>
        <td id="LC5849" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">their work as in their subjects. Teniers the Younger (1610-1690) was</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5850" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5850"></td>
        <td id="LC5850" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">among the first of them to picture peasant, burgher, alewife, and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5851" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5851"></td>
        <td id="LC5851" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">nobleman in all scenes and places. Nothing escaped him as a subject,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5852" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5852"></td>
        <td id="LC5852" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">and yet his best work was shown in the handling of low life in</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5853" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5853"></td>
        <td id="LC5853" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">taverns. There is coarse wit in his work, but it is atoned for by</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5854" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5854"></td>
        <td id="LC5854" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">good color and easy handling. He was influenced by Rubens, though</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5855" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5855"></td>
        <td id="LC5855" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">decidedly different from him in many respects. Brouwer (1606?-1638)</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5856" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5856"></td>
        <td id="LC5856" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">has often been catalogued with the Holland school, but he really</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5857" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5857"></td>
        <td id="LC5857" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">belongs with Teniers, in Belgium. He died early, but left a number of</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5858" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5858"></td>
        <td id="LC5858" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">pictures remarkable for their fine &quot;fat&quot; quality and their beautiful</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5859" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5859"></td>
        <td id="LC5859" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">color. He was not a man of Italian imagination, but a painter of low</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5860" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5860"></td>
        <td id="LC5860" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">life, with coarse humor and not too much good taste, yet a superb</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5861" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5861"></td>
        <td id="LC5861" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">technician and vastly beyond many of his little Dutch contemporaries</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5862" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5862"></td>
        <td id="LC5862" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">at the North. Teniers and Brouwer led a school and had many followers.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5863" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5863"></td>
        <td id="LC5863" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5864" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5864"></td>
        <td id="LC5864" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">In a slightly different vein was Gonzales Coques (1618-1684), who is</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5865" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5865"></td>
        <td id="LC5865" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">generally seen to advantage in pictures of interiors with family</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5866" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5866"></td>
        <td id="LC5866" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">groups. In subject he was more refined than the other _genre_</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5867" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5867"></td>
        <td id="LC5867" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">painters, and was influenced to some extent by Van Dyck. As a colorist</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5868" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5868"></td>
        <td id="LC5868" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">he held rank, and his portraiture (rarely seen) was excellent. At this</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5869" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5869"></td>
        <td id="LC5869" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">time there were also many painters of landscape, marine, battles,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5870" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5870"></td>
        <td id="LC5870" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">still-life--in fact Belgium was alive with painters--but none of them</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5871" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5871"></td>
        <td id="LC5871" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">was sufficiently great to call for individual mention. Most of them</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5872" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5872"></td>
        <td id="LC5872" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">were followers of either Holland or Italy, and the gist of their work</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5873" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5873"></td>
        <td id="LC5873" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">will be spoken of hereafter under Dutch painting.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5874" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5874"></td>
        <td id="LC5874" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5875" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5875"></td>
        <td id="LC5875" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">EIGHTEENTH-CENTURY PAINTING IN BELGIUM: Decline had set in before the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5876" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5876"></td>
        <td id="LC5876" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">seventeenth century ended. Belgium was torn by wars, her commerce</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5877" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5877"></td>
        <td id="LC5877" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">flagged, her art-spirit seemed burned out. A long line of petty</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5878" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5878"></td>
        <td id="LC5878" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">painters followed whose works call for silence. One man alone seemed</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5879" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5879"></td>
        <td id="LC5879" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">to stand out like a star by comparison with his contemporaries,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5880" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5880"></td>
        <td id="LC5880" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Verhagen (1728-1811), a portrait-painter of talent.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5881" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5881"></td>
        <td id="LC5881" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5882" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5882"></td>
        <td id="LC5882" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">NINETEENTH-CENTURY PAINTING IN BELGIUM: During this century Belgium</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5883" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5883"></td>
        <td id="LC5883" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">has been so closely related to France that the influence of the larger</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5884" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5884"></td>
        <td id="LC5884" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">country has been quite apparent upon the art of the smaller. In 1816</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5885" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5885"></td>
        <td id="LC5885" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">David, the leader of the French classic school, sent into exile by the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5886" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5886"></td>
        <td id="LC5886" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Restoration, settled at Brussels, and immediately drew around him</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5887" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5887"></td>
        <td id="LC5887" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">many pupils. His influence was felt at once, and Francois Navez</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5888" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5888"></td>
        <td id="LC5888" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">(1787-1869) was the chief one among his pupils to establish the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5889" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5889"></td>
        <td id="LC5889" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">revived classic art in Belgium. In 1830, with Belgian independence and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5890" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5890"></td>
        <td id="LC5890" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">almost concurrently with the romantic movement in France, there began</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5891" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5891"></td>
        <td id="LC5891" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">a romantic movement in Belgium with Wappers (1803-1874). His art was</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5892" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5892"></td>
        <td id="LC5892" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">founded substantially on Rubens; but, like the Paris romanticists, he</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5893" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5893"></td>
        <td id="LC5893" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">chose the dramatic subject of the times and treated it more for color</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5894" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5894"></td>
        <td id="LC5894" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">than for line. He drew a number of followers to himself, but the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5895" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5895"></td>
        <td id="LC5895" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">movement was not more lasting than in France.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5896" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5896"></td>
        <td id="LC5896" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5897" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5897"></td>
        <td id="LC5897" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Wiertz (1806-1865), whose collection of works is to be seen in</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5898" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5898"></td>
        <td id="LC5898" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Brussels, was a partial exposition of romanticism mixed with a</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5899" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5899"></td>
        <td id="LC5899" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">what-not of eccentricity entirely his own. Later on came a</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5900" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5900"></td>
        <td id="LC5900" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">comparatively new man, Louis Gallait (1810-?), who held in Brussels</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5901" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5901"></td>
        <td id="LC5901" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">substantially the same position that Delaroche did in Paris. His art</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5902" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5902"></td>
        <td id="LC5902" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">was eclectic and never strong, though he had many pupils at Brussels,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5903" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5903"></td>
        <td id="LC5903" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">and started there a rivalry to Wappers at Antwerp. Leys (1815-1869)</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5904" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5904"></td>
        <td id="LC5904" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">holds a rather unique position in Belgian art by reason of his</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5905" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5905"></td>
        <td id="LC5905" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">affectation. He at first followed Pieter de Hooghe and other early</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5906" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5906"></td>
        <td id="LC5906" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">painters. Then, after a study of the old German painters like Cranach,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5907" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5907"></td>
        <td id="LC5907" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">he developed an archaic style, producing a Gothic quaintness of line</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5908" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5908"></td>
        <td id="LC5908" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">and composition, mingled with old Flemish coloring. The result was</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5909" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5909"></td>
        <td id="LC5909" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">something popular, but not original or far-reaching, though</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5910" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5910"></td>
        <td id="LC5910" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">technically well done. His chief pupil was Alma Tadema (1836-), alive</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5911" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5911"></td>
        <td id="LC5911" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">to-day in London, and belonging to no school in particular. He is a</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5912" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5912"></td>
        <td id="LC5912" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">technician of ability, mannered in composition and subject, and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5913" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5913"></td>
        <td id="LC5913" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">somewhat perfunctory in execution. His work is very popular with those</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5914" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5914"></td>
        <td id="LC5914" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">who enjoy minute detail and smooth texture-painting.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5915" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5915"></td>
        <td id="LC5915" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5916" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5916"></td>
        <td id="LC5916" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">In 1851 the influence of the French realism of Courbet began to be</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5917" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5917"></td>
        <td id="LC5917" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">felt at Brussels, and since then Belgian art has followed closely the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5918" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5918"></td>
        <td id="LC5918" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">art movements at Paris. Men like Alfred Stevens (1828-), a pupil of</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5919" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5919"></td>
        <td id="LC5919" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Navez, are really more French than Belgian. Stevens is one of the best</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5920" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5920"></td>
        <td id="LC5920" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">of the moderns, a painter of power in fashionable or high-life</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5921" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5921"></td>
        <td id="LC5921" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">_genre_, and a colorist of the first rank in modern art. Among the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5922" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5922"></td>
        <td id="LC5922" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">recent painters but a few can be mentioned. Willems (1823-), a weak</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5923" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5923"></td>
        <td id="LC5923" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">painter of fashionable _genre_; Verboeckhoven (1799-1881), a vastly</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5924" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5924"></td>
        <td id="LC5924" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">over-estimated animal painter; Clays (1819-), an excellent marine</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5925" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5925"></td>
        <td id="LC5925" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">painter; Boulanger, a landscapist; Wauters (1846-), a history, and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5926" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5926"></td>
        <td id="LC5926" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">portrait-painter; Jan van Beers and Robie. The new men are Claus,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5927" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5927"></td>
        <td id="LC5927" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Buysse, Frederic, Khnopff, Lempoels.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5928" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5928"></td>
        <td id="LC5928" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5929" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5929"></td>
        <td id="LC5929" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">[Illustration: FIG. 80.--ALFRED STEVENS. ON THE BEACH.]</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5930" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5930"></td>
        <td id="LC5930" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5931" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5931"></td>

      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5932" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5932"></td>

        <td id="L5951" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5951"></td>

      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5955" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5955"></td>
        <td id="LC5955" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     Vienna, Hague, Brussels, Cassel, Louvre, St. Petersburg</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5956" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5956"></td>
        <td id="LC5956" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     Mus.; Bril, landscapes Madrid, Louvre, Dresden, Berlin Mus.;</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5957" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5957"></td>
        <td id="LC5957" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     the landscapes of the three Breughels are to be seen in most</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5958" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5958"></td>
        <td id="LC5958" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     of the museums of Europe, especially at Munich, Dresden, and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L5959" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="5959"></td>

        <td id="L6004" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6004"></td>
        <td id="LC6004" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">CHAPTER XVII.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6005" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6005"></td>
        <td id="LC6005" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6006" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6006"></td>
        <td id="LC6006" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">DUTCH PAINTING.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6007" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6007"></td>
        <td id="LC6007" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6008" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6008"></td>
        <td id="LC6008" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     BOOKS RECOMMENDED: As before Fromentin, (Waagen&#39;s) Kuegler;</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6009" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6009"></td>
        <td id="LC6009" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     Amand-Durand, _OEuvre de Rembrandt_; _Archief voor</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6010" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6010"></td>
        <td id="LC6010" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     Nederlandsche Kunst-geschiedenis_; Blanc, _OEuvre de</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6011" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6011"></td>
        <td id="LC6011" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     Rembrandt_; Bode, _Franz Hals und seine Schule_; Bode,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6012" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6012"></td>
        <td id="LC6012" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     _Studien zur Geschichte der Hollandischen Malerei_; Bode,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6013" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6013"></td>

      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6014" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6014"></td>
        <td id="LC6014" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     Thore), _Les Musees de la Hollande_; Havard, _La Peinture</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6015" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6015"></td>
        <td id="LC6015" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     Hollandaise_; Michel, _Rembrandt_; Michel, _Gerard Terburg</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6016" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6016"></td>
        <td id="LC6016" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     et sa Famille_; Mantz, _Adrien Brouwer_; Rooses, _Dutch</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6017" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6017"></td>

      <tr>
        <td id="L6018" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6018"></td>
        <td id="LC6018" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     Schmidt, _Das Leben des Malers Adriaen Brouwer_; Van der</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6019" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6019"></td>
        <td id="LC6019" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     Willigen, _Les Artistes de Harlem_; Van Mander, _Leven der</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6020" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6020"></td>
        <td id="LC6020" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     Nederlandsche en Hoogduitsche Schilders_; Vosmaer,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6021" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6021"></td>
        <td id="LC6021" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     _Rembrandt, sa Vie et ses OEuvres_; Westrheene, _Jan</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6022" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6022"></td>
        <td id="LC6022" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     Steen, Etude sur l&#39;Art en Hollande_; Van Dyke, _Old Dutch</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6023" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6023"></td>
        <td id="LC6023" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     and Flemish Masters_.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6024" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6024"></td>
        <td id="LC6024" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6025" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6025"></td>
        <td id="LC6025" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6026" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6026"></td>
        <td id="LC6026" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">THE DUTCH PEOPLE AND THEIR ART: Though Holland produced a somewhat</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6027" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6027"></td>
        <td id="LC6027" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">different quality of art from Flanders and Belgium, yet in many</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6028" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6028"></td>
        <td id="LC6028" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">respects the people at the north were not very different from those at</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6029" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6029"></td>
        <td id="LC6029" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">the south of the Netherlands. They were perhaps less versatile, less</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6030" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6030"></td>
        <td id="LC6030" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">volatile, less like the French and more like the Germans. Fond of</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6031" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6031"></td>
        <td id="LC6031" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">homely joys and the quiet peace of town and domestic life, the Dutch</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6032" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6032"></td>
        <td id="LC6032" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">were matter-of-fact in all things, sturdy, honest, coarse at times,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6033" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6033"></td>
        <td id="LC6033" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">sufficient unto themselves, and caring little for what other people</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6034" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6034"></td>
        <td id="LC6034" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">did. Just so with their painters. They were realistic at times to</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6035" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6035"></td>
        <td id="LC6035" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">grotesqueness. Little troubled with fine poetic frenzies they painted</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6036" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6036"></td>
        <td id="LC6036" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">their own lives in street, town-hall, tavern, and kitchen, conscious</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6037" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6037"></td>
        <td id="LC6037" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">that it was good because true to themselves.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6038" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6038"></td>
        <td id="LC6038" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6039" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6039"></td>
        <td id="LC6039" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">At first Dutch art was influenced, even confounded, with that of</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6040" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6040"></td>
        <td id="LC6040" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Flanders. The Van Eycks led the way, and painters like Bouts and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6041" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6041"></td>
        <td id="LC6041" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">others, though Dutch by birth, became Flemish by adoption in their art</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6042" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6042"></td>
        <td id="LC6042" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">at least. When the Flemish painters fell to copying Italy some of the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6043" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6043"></td>
        <td id="LC6043" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Dutch followed them, but with no great enthusiasm. Suddenly, at the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6044" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6044"></td>
        <td id="LC6044" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">beginning of the seventeenth century, when Holland had gained</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6045" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6045"></td>
        <td id="LC6045" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">political independence, Dutch art struck off by itself, became</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6046" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6046"></td>
        <td id="LC6046" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">original, became famous. It pictured native life with verve, skill,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6047" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6047"></td>
        <td id="LC6047" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">keenness of insight, and fine pictorial view. Limited it was; it never</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6048" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6048"></td>
        <td id="LC6048" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">soared like Italian art, never became universal or world-embracing. It</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6049" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6049"></td>
        <td id="LC6049" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">was distinct, individual, national, something that spoke for Holland,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6050" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6050"></td>
        <td id="LC6050" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">but little beyond it.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6051" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6051"></td>
        <td id="LC6051" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6052" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6052"></td>
        <td id="LC6052" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">In subject there were few historical canvases such as the Italians and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6053" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6053"></td>
        <td id="LC6053" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">French produced. The nearest approach to them were the paintings of</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6054" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6054"></td>
        <td id="LC6054" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">shooting companies, or groups of burghers and syndics, and these were</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6055" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6055"></td>
        <td id="LC6055" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">merely elaborations and enlargements of the portrait which the Dutch</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6056" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6056"></td>
        <td id="LC6056" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">loved best of all. As a whole their subjects were single figures or</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6057" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6057"></td>
        <td id="LC6057" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">small groups in interiors, quiet scenes, family conferences, smokers,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6058" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6058"></td>
        <td id="LC6058" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">card-players, drinkers, landscapes, still-life, architectural pieces.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6059" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6059"></td>
        <td id="LC6059" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">When they undertook the large canvas with many figures, they were</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6060" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6060"></td>
        <td id="LC6060" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">often unsatisfactory. Even Rembrandt was so. The chief medium was oil,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6061" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6061"></td>
        <td id="LC6061" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">used upon panel or canvas. Fresco was probably used in the early days,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6062" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6062"></td>
        <td id="LC6062" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">but the climate was too damp for it and it was abandoned. It was</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6063" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6063"></td>
        <td id="LC6063" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">perhaps the dampness of the northern climate that led to the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6064" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6064"></td>
        <td id="LC6064" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">adaptation of the oil medium, something the Van Eycks are credited</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6065" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6065"></td>
        <td id="LC6065" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">with inaugurating.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6066" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6066"></td>
        <td id="LC6066" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6067" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6067"></td>
        <td id="LC6067" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">[Illustration: FIG. 81.--HALS. PORTRAIT OF A LADY.]</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6068" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6068"></td>
        <td id="LC6068" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6069" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6069"></td>
        <td id="LC6069" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">THE EARLY PAINTING: The early work has, for the great part, perished</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6070" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6070"></td>
        <td id="LC6070" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">through time and the fierceness with which the Iconoclastic warfare</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6071" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6071"></td>
        <td id="LC6071" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">was waged. That which remains to-day is closely allied in method and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6072" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6072"></td>
        <td id="LC6072" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">style to Flemish painting under the Van Eycks. Ouwater is one of the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6073" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6073"></td>
        <td id="LC6073" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">earliest names that appears, and perhaps for that reason he has been</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6074" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6074"></td>
        <td id="LC6074" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">called the founder of the school. He was remarked in his time for the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6075" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6075"></td>
        <td id="LC6075" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">excellent painting of background landscapes; but there is little</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6076" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6076"></td>
        <td id="LC6076" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">authentic by him left to us from which we may form an opinion.[17]</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6077" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6077"></td>
        <td id="LC6077" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Geertjen van St. Jan (about 1475) was evidently a pupil of his, and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6078" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6078"></td>
        <td id="LC6078" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">from him there are two wings of an altar in the Vienna Gallery,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6079" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6079"></td>
        <td id="LC6079" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">supposed to be genuine. Bouts and Mostert have been spoken of under</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6080" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6080"></td>
        <td id="LC6080" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">the Flemish school. Bosch (1460?-1516) was a man of some individuality</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6081" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6081"></td>
        <td id="LC6081" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">who produced fantastic purgatories that were popular in their time and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6082" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6082"></td>
        <td id="LC6082" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">are known to-day through engravings. Engelbrechsten (1468-1533) was</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6083" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6083"></td>
        <td id="LC6083" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Dutch by birth and in his art, and yet probably got his inspiration</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6084" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6084"></td>
        <td id="LC6084" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">from the Van Eyck school. The works attributed to him are doubtful,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6085" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6085"></td>
        <td id="LC6085" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">though two in the Leyden Gallery seem to be authentic. He was the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6086" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6086"></td>
        <td id="LC6086" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">master of Lucas van Leyden (1494-1533), the leading artist of the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6087" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6087"></td>
        <td id="LC6087" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">early period. Lucas van Leyden was a personal friend of Albrecht</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6088" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6088"></td>
        <td id="LC6088" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Duerer, the German painter, and in his art he was not unlike him. A</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6089" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6089"></td>
        <td id="LC6089" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">man with a singularly lean type, a little awkward in composition,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6090" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6090"></td>
        <td id="LC6090" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">brilliant in color, and warm in tone, he was, despite his</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6091" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6091"></td>
        <td id="LC6091" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">archaic-looking work, an artist of much ability and originality. At</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6092" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6092"></td>
        <td id="LC6092" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">first he was inclined toward Flemish methods, with an exaggerated</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6093" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6093"></td>
        <td id="LC6093" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">realism in facial expression. In his middle period he was distinctly</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6094" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6094"></td>
        <td id="LC6094" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Dutch, but in his later days he came under Italian influence, and with</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6095" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6095"></td>
        <td id="LC6095" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">a weakening effect upon his art. Taking his work as a whole, it was</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6096" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6096"></td>
        <td id="LC6096" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">the strongest of all the early Dutch painters.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6097" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6097"></td>
        <td id="LC6097" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6098" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6098"></td>
        <td id="LC6098" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">[Footnote 17: A Raising of Lazarus is in the Berlin Gallery.]</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6099" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6099"></td>
        <td id="LC6099" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6100" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6100"></td>
        <td id="LC6100" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">SIXTEENTH CENTURY: This century was a period of Italian imitation,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6101" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6101"></td>
        <td id="LC6101" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">probably superinduced by the action of the Flemings at Antwerp. The</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6102" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6102"></td>
        <td id="LC6102" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">movement was somewhat like the Flemish one, but not so extensive or so</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6103" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6103"></td>
        <td id="LC6103" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">productive. There was hardly a painter of rank in Holland during the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6104" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6104"></td>
        <td id="LC6104" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">whole century. Scorel (1495-1562) was the leader, and he probably got</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6105" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6105"></td>
        <td id="LC6105" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">his first liking for Italian art through Mabuse at Antwerp. He</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6106" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6106"></td>
        <td id="LC6106" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">afterward went to Italy, studied Raphael and Michael Angelo, and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6107" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6107"></td>
        <td id="LC6107" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">returned to Utrecht to open a school and introduce Italian art into</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6108" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6108"></td>
        <td id="LC6108" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Holland. A large number of pupils followed him, but their work was</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6109" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6109"></td>
        <td id="LC6109" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">lacking in true originality. Heemskerck (1498-1574) and Cornelis van</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6110" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6110"></td>
        <td id="LC6110" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Haarlem (1562-1638), with Steenwyck (1550?-1604), were some of the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6111" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6111"></td>
        <td id="LC6111" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">more important men of the century, but none of them was above a common</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6112" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6112"></td>
        <td id="LC6112" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">average.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6113" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6113"></td>
        <td id="LC6113" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6114" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6114"></td>
        <td id="LC6114" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">SEVENTEENTH CENTURY: Beginning with the first quarter of this century</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6115" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6115"></td>
        <td id="LC6115" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">came the great art of the Dutch people, founded on themselves and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6116" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6116"></td>
        <td id="LC6116" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">rooted in their native character. Italian methods were abandoned, and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6117" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6117"></td>
        <td id="LC6117" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">the Dutch told the story of their own lives in their own manner, with</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6118" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6118"></td>
        <td id="LC6118" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">truth, vigor, and skill. There were so many painters in Holland during</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6119" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6119"></td>
        <td id="LC6119" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">this period that it will be necessary to divide them into groups and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6120" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6120"></td>
        <td id="LC6120" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">mention only the prominent names.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6121" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6121"></td>
        <td id="LC6121" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6122" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6122"></td>
        <td id="LC6122" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">PORTRAIT AND FIGURE PAINTERS: The real inaugurators of Dutch</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6123" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6123"></td>
        <td id="LC6123" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">portraiture were Mierevelt, Hals, Ravesteyn, and De Keyser. Mierevelt</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6124" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6124"></td>
        <td id="LC6124" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">(1567-1641) was one of the earliest, a prolific painter, fond of the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6125" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6125"></td>
        <td id="LC6125" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">aristocratic sitter, and indulging in a great deal of elegance in his</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6126" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6126"></td>
        <td id="LC6126" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">accessories of dress and the like. He had a slight, smooth brush, much</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6127" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6127"></td>
        <td id="LC6127" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">detail, and a profusion of color. Quite the reverse of him was Franz</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6128" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6128"></td>
        <td id="LC6128" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Hals (1584?-1666), one of the most remarkable painters of portraits</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6129" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6129"></td>
        <td id="LC6129" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">with which history acquaints us. In giving the sense of life and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6130" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6130"></td>
        <td id="LC6130" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">personal physical presence, he was unexcelled by any one. What he saw</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6131" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6131"></td>
        <td id="LC6131" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">he could portray with the most telling reality. In drawing and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6132" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6132"></td>
        <td id="LC6132" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">modelling he was usually good; in coloring he was excellent, though in</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6133" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6133"></td>
        <td id="LC6133" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">his late work sombre; in brush-handling he was one of the great</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6134" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6134"></td>
        <td id="LC6134" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">masters. Strong, virile, yet easy and facile, he seemed to produce</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6135" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6135"></td>
        <td id="LC6135" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">without effort. His brush was very broad in its sweep, very sure, very</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6136" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6136"></td>
        <td id="LC6136" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">true. Occasionally in his late painting facility ran to the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6137" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6137"></td>
        <td id="LC6137" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">ineffectual, but usually he was certainty itself. His best work was in</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6138" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6138"></td>
        <td id="LC6138" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">portraiture, and the most important of this is to be seen at Haarlem,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6139" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6139"></td>
        <td id="LC6139" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">where he died after a rather careless life. As a painter, pure and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6140" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6140"></td>
        <td id="LC6140" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">simple, he is almost to be ranked beside Velasquez; as a poet, a</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6141" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6141"></td>
        <td id="LC6141" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">thinker, a man of lofty imagination, his work gives us little</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6142" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6142"></td>
        <td id="LC6142" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">enlightenment except in so far as it shows a fine feeling for masses</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6143" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6143"></td>
        <td id="LC6143" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">of color and problems of light. Though excellent portrait-painters,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6144" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6144"></td>
        <td id="LC6144" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Ravesteyn (1572?-1657) and De Keyser (1596?-1679) do not provoke</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6145" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6145"></td>
        <td id="LC6145" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">enthusiasm. They were quiet, conservative, dignified, painting civic</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6146" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6146"></td>
        <td id="LC6146" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">guards and societies with a knowing brush and lively color, giving the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6147" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6147"></td>
        <td id="LC6147" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">truth of physiognomy, but not with that verve of the artist so</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6148" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6148"></td>
        <td id="LC6148" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">conspicuous in Hals, nor with that unity of the group so essential in</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6149" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6149"></td>
        <td id="LC6149" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">the making of a picture.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6150" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6150"></td>
        <td id="LC6150" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6151" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6151"></td>
        <td id="LC6151" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">[Illustration: FIG. 82.--REMBRANDT. HEAD OF WOMAN. NAT. GAL. LONDON.]</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6152" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6152"></td>
        <td id="LC6152" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6153" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6153"></td>
        <td id="LC6153" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">The next man in chronological order is Rembrandt (1607?-1669), the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6154" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6154"></td>
        <td id="LC6154" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">greatest painter in Dutch art. He was a pupil of Swanenburch and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6155" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6155"></td>
        <td id="LC6155" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Lastman, but his great knowledge of nature and his craft came largely</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6156" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6156"></td>
        <td id="LC6156" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">from the direct study of the model. Settled at Amsterdam, he quickly</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6157" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6157"></td>
        <td id="LC6157" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">rose to fame, had a large following of pupils, and his influence was</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6158" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6158"></td>
        <td id="LC6158" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">felt through all Dutch painting. The portrait was emphatically his</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
