        <td id="L6159" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6159"></td>
        <td id="LC6159" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">strongest work. The many-figured group he was not always successful in</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6160" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6160"></td>
        <td id="LC6160" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">composing or lighting. His method of work rather fitted him for the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6161" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6161"></td>
        <td id="LC6161" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">portrait and unfitted him for the large historical piece. He built up</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6162" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6162"></td>
        <td id="LC6162" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">the importance of certain features by dragging down all other</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6163" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6163"></td>
        <td id="LC6163" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">features. This was largely shown in his handling of illumination.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6164" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6164"></td>
        <td id="LC6164" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Strong in a few high lights on cheek, chin, or white linen, the rest</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6165" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6165"></td>
        <td id="LC6165" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">of the picture was submerged in shadow, under which color was</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6166" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6166"></td>
        <td id="LC6166" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">unmercifully sacrificed. This was not the best method for a large,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6167" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6167"></td>
        <td id="LC6167" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">many-figured piece, but was singularly well suited to the portrait. It</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6168" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6168"></td>
        <td id="LC6168" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">produced strength by contrast. &quot;Forced&quot; it was undoubtedly, and not</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6169" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6169"></td>
        <td id="LC6169" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">always true to nature, yet nevertheless most potent in Rembrandt&#39;s</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6170" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6170"></td>
        <td id="LC6170" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">hands. He was an arbitrary though perfect master of light-and-shade,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6171" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6171"></td>
        <td id="LC6171" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">and unusually effective in luminous and transparent shadows. In color</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6172" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6172"></td>
        <td id="LC6172" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">he was again arbitrary but forcible and harmonious. In brush-work he</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6173" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6173"></td>
        <td id="LC6173" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">was at times labored, but almost always effective.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6174" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6174"></td>
        <td id="LC6174" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6175" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6175"></td>
        <td id="LC6175" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Mentally he was a man keen to observe, assimilate, and express his</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6176" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6176"></td>
        <td id="LC6176" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">impressions in a few simple truths. His conception was localized with</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6177" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6177"></td>
        <td id="LC6177" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">his own people and time (he never built up the imaginary or followed</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6178" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6178"></td>
        <td id="LC6178" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Italy), and yet into types taken from the streets and shops of</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6179" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6179"></td>
        <td id="LC6179" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Amsterdam he infused the very largest humanity through his inherent</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6180" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6180"></td>
        <td id="LC6180" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">sympathy with man. Dramatic, even tragic, he was; yet this was not so</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6181" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6181"></td>
        <td id="LC6181" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">apparent in vehement action as in passionate expression. He had a</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6182" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6182"></td>
        <td id="LC6182" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">powerful way of striking universal truths through the human face, the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6183" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6183"></td>
        <td id="LC6183" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">turned head, bent body, or outstretched hand. His people have</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6184" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6184"></td>
        <td id="LC6184" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">character, dignity, and a pervading feeling that they are the great</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6185" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6185"></td>
        <td id="LC6185" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">types of the Dutch race--people of substantial physique, slow in</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6186" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6186"></td>
        <td id="LC6186" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">thought and impulse, yet capable of feeling, comprehending, enjoying,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6187" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6187"></td>
        <td id="LC6187" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">suffering.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6188" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6188"></td>
        <td id="LC6188" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6189" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6189"></td>
        <td id="LC6189" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">His landscapes, again, were a synthesis of all landscapes, a grouping</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6190" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6190"></td>
        <td id="LC6190" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">of the great truths of light, air, shadow, space. Whatever he turned</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6191" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6191"></td>
        <td id="LC6191" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">his hand to was treated with that breadth of view that overlooked the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6192" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6192"></td>
        <td id="LC6192" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">little and grasped the great. He painted many subjects. His earliest</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6193" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6193"></td>
        <td id="LC6193" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">work dates from 1627, and is a little hard and sharp in detail and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6194" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6194"></td>
        <td id="LC6194" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">cold in coloring. After 1654 he grew broader in handling and warmer in</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6195" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6195"></td>
        <td id="LC6195" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">tone, running to golden browns, and, toward the end of his career, to</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6196" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6196"></td>
        <td id="LC6196" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">rather hot tones. His life was embittered by many misfortunes, but</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6197" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6197"></td>
        <td id="LC6197" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">these never seem to have affected his art except to deepen it. He</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6198" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6198"></td>
        <td id="LC6198" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">painted on to the last, convinced that his own view was the true one,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6199" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6199"></td>
        <td id="LC6199" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">and producing works that rank second to none in the history of</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6200" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6200"></td>
        <td id="LC6200" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">painting.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6201" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6201"></td>
        <td id="LC6201" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6202" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6202"></td>
        <td id="LC6202" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Rembrandt&#39;s influence upon Dutch art was far-reaching, and appeared</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6203" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6203"></td>
        <td id="LC6203" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">immediately in the works of his many pupils. They all followed his</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6204" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6204"></td>
        <td id="LC6204" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">methods of handling light-and-shade, but no one of them ever equalled</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6205" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6205"></td>
        <td id="LC6205" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">him, though they produced work of much merit. Bol (1611-1680) was</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6206" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6206"></td>
        <td id="LC6206" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">chiefly a portrait-painter, with a pervading yellow tone and some</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6207" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6207"></td>
        <td id="LC6207" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">pallor of flesh-coloring--a man of ability who mistakenly followed</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6208" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6208"></td>
        <td id="LC6208" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Rubens in the latter part of his life. Flinck (1615-1660) at one time</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6209" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6209"></td>
        <td id="LC6209" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">followed Rembrandt so closely that his work has passed for that of the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6210" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6210"></td>
        <td id="LC6210" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">master; but latterly he, too, came under Flemish influence. Next to</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6211" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6211"></td>
        <td id="LC6211" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Eeckhout he was probably the nearest to Rembrandt in methods of all</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6212" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6212"></td>
        <td id="LC6212" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">the pupils. Eeckhout (1621-1674) was really a Rembrandt imitator, but</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6213" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6213"></td>
        <td id="LC6213" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">his hand was weak and his color hot. Maes (1632-1693) was the most</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6214" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6214"></td>
        <td id="LC6214" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">successful manager of light after the school formula, and succeeded</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6215" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6215"></td>
        <td id="LC6215" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">very well with warmth and richness of color, especially with his reds.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6216" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6216"></td>
        <td id="LC6216" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">The other Rembrandt pupils and followers were Poorter (fl. 1635-1643),</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6217" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6217"></td>
        <td id="LC6217" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Victoors (1620?-1672?), Koninck (1619-1688), Fabritius (1624-1654),</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6218" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6218"></td>
        <td id="LC6218" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">and Backer (1608?-1651).</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6219" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6219"></td>
        <td id="LC6219" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6220" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6220"></td>
        <td id="LC6220" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Van der Helst (1612?-1670) stands apart from this school, and seems to</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6221" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6221"></td>
        <td id="LC6221" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">have followed more the portrait style of De Keyser. He was a</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6222" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6222"></td>
        <td id="LC6222" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">realistic, precise painter, with much excellence of modelling in head</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6223" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6223"></td>
        <td id="LC6223" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">and hands, and with fine carriage and dignity in the figure. In</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6224" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6224"></td>
        <td id="LC6224" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">composition he hardly held his characters in group owing to a</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6225" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6225"></td>
        <td id="LC6225" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">sacrifice of values, and in color he was often &quot;spotty,&quot; and lacking</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6226" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6226"></td>
        <td id="LC6226" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">in the unity of mass.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6227" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6227"></td>
        <td id="LC6227" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6228" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6228"></td>
        <td id="LC6228" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">THE GENRE PAINTERS: This heading embraces those who may be called the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6229" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6229"></td>
        <td id="LC6229" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">&quot;Little Dutchmen,&quot; because of the small scale of their pictures and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6230" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6230"></td>
        <td id="LC6230" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">their _genre_ subjects. Gerard Dou (1613-1675) is indicative of the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6231" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6231"></td>
        <td id="LC6231" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">class without fully representing it. He was a pupil of Rembrandt, but</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6232" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6232"></td>
        <td id="LC6232" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">his work gave little report of this. It was smaller, more delicate in</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6233" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6233"></td>
        <td id="LC6233" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">detail, more petty in conception. He was a man great in little</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6234" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6234"></td>
        <td id="LC6234" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">things, one who wasted strength on the minutiae of dress, or</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6235" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6235"></td>
        <td id="LC6235" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">table-cloth, or the texture of furniture without grasping the mass or</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6236" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6236"></td>
        <td id="LC6236" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">color significance of the whole scene. There was infinite detail about</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6237" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6237"></td>
        <td id="LC6237" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">his work, and that gave it popularity; but as art it held, and holds</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6238" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6238"></td>
        <td id="LC6238" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">to-day, little higher place than the work of Metsu (1630-1667), Van</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6239" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6239"></td>
        <td id="LC6239" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Mieris (1635-1681), Netscher (1639-1684), or Schalcken (1643-1706),</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6240" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6240"></td>
        <td id="LC6240" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">all of whom produced the interior piece with figures elaborate in</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6241" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6241"></td>
        <td id="LC6241" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">accidental effects. Van Ostade (1610-1685), though dealing with the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6242" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6242"></td>
        <td id="LC6242" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">small canvas, and portraying peasant life with perhaps unnecessary</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6243" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6243"></td>
        <td id="LC6243" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">coarseness, was a much stronger painter than the men just mentioned.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6244" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6244"></td>
        <td id="LC6244" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">He was the favorite pupil of Hals and the master of Jan Steen. With</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6245" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6245"></td>
        <td id="LC6245" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">little delicacy in choice of subject he had much delicacy in color,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6246" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6246"></td>
        <td id="LC6246" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">taste in arrangement, and skill in handling. His brush was precise but</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6247" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6247"></td>
        <td id="LC6247" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">not finical.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6248" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6248"></td>
        <td id="LC6248" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6249" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6249"></td>
        <td id="LC6249" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">[Illustration: FIG. 83.--J. VAN RUISDAEL. LANDSCAPE.]</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6250" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6250"></td>
        <td id="LC6250" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6251" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6251"></td>
        <td id="LC6251" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">By far the best painter among all the &quot;Little Dutchmen&quot; was Terburg</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6252" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6252"></td>
        <td id="LC6252" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">(1617?-1681), a painter of interiors, small portraits, conversation</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6253" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6253"></td>
        <td id="LC6253" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">pictures, and the like. Though of diminutive scale his work has the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6254" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6254"></td>
        <td id="LC6254" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">largeness of view characteristic of genius, and the skilled technic of</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6255" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6255"></td>
        <td id="LC6255" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">a thorough craftsman. Terburg was a travelled man, visiting Italy,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6256" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6256"></td>
        <td id="LC6256" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">where he studied Titian, returning to Holland to study Rembrandt,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6257" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6257"></td>
        <td id="LC6257" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">finally at Madrid studying Velasquez. He was a painter of much</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6258" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6258"></td>
        <td id="LC6258" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">culture, and the keynote of his art is refinement. Quiet and dignified</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6259" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6259"></td>
        <td id="LC6259" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">he carried taste through all branches of his art. In subject he was</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6260" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6260"></td>
        <td id="LC6260" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">rather elevated, in color subdued with broken tones, in composition</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6261" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6261"></td>
        <td id="LC6261" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">simple, in brush-work sure, vivacious, and yet unobtrusive. Selection</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6262" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6262"></td>
        <td id="LC6262" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">in his characters was followed by reserve in using them. Detail was</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6263" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6263"></td>
        <td id="LC6263" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">not very apparent. A few people with some accessory objects were all</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6264" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6264"></td>
        <td id="LC6264" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">that he required to make a picture. Perhaps his best qualities appear</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6265" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6265"></td>
        <td id="LC6265" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">in a number of small portraits remarkable for their distinction and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6266" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6266"></td>
        <td id="LC6266" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">aristocratic grace.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6267" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6267"></td>
        <td id="LC6267" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6268" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6268"></td>
        <td id="LC6268" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Steen (1626?-1679) was almost the opposite of Terburg, a man of</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6269" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6269"></td>
        <td id="LC6269" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">sarcastic flings and coarse humor who satirized his own time with</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6270" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6270"></td>
        <td id="LC6270" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">little reserve. He developed under Hals and Van Ostade, favoring the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6271" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6271"></td>
        <td id="LC6271" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">latter in his interiors, family scenes, and drunken debauches. He was</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6272" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6272"></td>
        <td id="LC6272" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">a master of physiognomy, and depicted it with rare if rather</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6273" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6273"></td>
        <td id="LC6273" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">unpleasant truth. If he had little refinement in his themes he</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6274" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6274"></td>
        <td id="LC6274" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">certainly handled them as a painter with delicacy. At his best his</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6275" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6275"></td>
        <td id="LC6275" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">many figured groups were exceedingly well composed, his color was of</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6276" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6276"></td>
        <td id="LC6276" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">good quality (with a fondness for yellows), and his brush was as</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6277" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6277"></td>
        <td id="LC6277" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">limpid and graceful as though painting angels instead of Dutch boors.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6278" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6278"></td>
        <td id="LC6278" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">He was really one of the fine brushmen of Holland, a man greatly</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6279" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6279"></td>
        <td id="LC6279" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">admired by Sir Joshua Reynolds, and many an artist since; but not a</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6280" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6280"></td>
        <td id="LC6280" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">man of high intellectual pitch as compared with Terburg, for</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6281" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6281"></td>
        <td id="LC6281" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">instance.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6282" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6282"></td>
        <td id="LC6282" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6283" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6283"></td>
        <td id="LC6283" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Pieter de Hooghe (1632?-1681) was a painter of purely pictorial</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6284" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6284"></td>
        <td id="LC6284" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">effects, beginning and ending a picture in a scheme of color,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6285" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6285"></td>
        <td id="LC6285" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">atmosphere, clever composition, and above all the play of</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6286" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6286"></td>
        <td id="LC6286" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">light-and-shade. He was one of the early masters of full sunlight,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6287" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6287"></td>
        <td id="LC6287" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">painting it falling across a court-yard or streaming through a window</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6288" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6288"></td>
        <td id="LC6288" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">with marvellous truth and poetry. His subjects were commonplace</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6289" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6289"></td>
        <td id="LC6289" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">enough. An interior with a figure or two in the middle distance, and a</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6290" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6290"></td>
        <td id="LC6290" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">passage-way leading into a lighted background were sufficient for him.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6291" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6291"></td>
        <td id="LC6291" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">These formed a skeleton which he clothed in a half-tone shadow,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6292" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6292"></td>
        <td id="LC6292" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">pierced with warm yellow light, enriched with rare colors, usually</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6293" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6293"></td>
        <td id="LC6293" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">garnet reds and deep yellows repeated in the different planes, and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6294" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6294"></td>
        <td id="LC6294" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">surrounded with a subtle pervading atmosphere. As a brushman he was</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6295" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6295"></td>
        <td id="LC6295" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">easy but not distinguished, and often his drawing was not correct; but</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6296" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6296"></td>
        <td id="LC6296" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">in the placing of color masses and in composing by color and light he</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6297" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6297"></td>
        <td id="LC6297" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">was a master of the first rank. Little is known about his life. He</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6298" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6298"></td>
        <td id="LC6298" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">probably formed himself on Fabritius or Rembrandt at second-hand, but</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6299" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6299"></td>
        <td id="LC6299" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">little trace of the latter is apparent in his work. He seems not to</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6300" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6300"></td>
        <td id="LC6300" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">have achieved much fame until late years, and then rather in England</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6301" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6301"></td>
        <td id="LC6301" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">than in his own country.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6302" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6302"></td>
        <td id="LC6302" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6303" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6303"></td>
        <td id="LC6303" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Jan van der Meer of Delft (1632-1675), one of the most charming of all</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6304" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6304"></td>
        <td id="LC6304" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">the _genre_ painters, was allied to De Hooghe in his pictorial point</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6305" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6305"></td>
        <td id="LC6305" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">of view and interior subjects. Unfortunately there is little left to</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6306" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6306"></td>
        <td id="LC6306" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">us of this master, but the few extant examples serve to show him a</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6307" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6307"></td>
        <td id="LC6307" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">painter of rare qualities in light, in color, and in atmosphere. He</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6308" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6308"></td>
        <td id="LC6308" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">was a remarkable man for his handling of blues, reds, and yellows; and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6309" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6309"></td>
        <td id="LC6309" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">in the tonic relations of a picture he was a master second to no one.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6310" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6310"></td>
        <td id="LC6310" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Fabritius is supposed to have influenced him.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6311" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6311"></td>
        <td id="LC6311" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6312" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6312"></td>
        <td id="LC6312" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">THE LANDSCAPE PAINTERS: The painters of the Netherlands were probably</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6313" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6313"></td>
        <td id="LC6313" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">the first, beginning with Bril, to paint landscape for its own sake,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6314" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6314"></td>
        <td id="LC6314" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">and as a picture motive in itself. Before them it had been used as a</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6315" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6315"></td>
        <td id="LC6315" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">background for the figure, and was so used by many of the Dutchmen</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6316" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6316"></td>
        <td id="LC6316" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">themselves. It has been said that these landscape-painters were also</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6317" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6317"></td>
        <td id="LC6317" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">the first ones to paint landscape realistically, but that is true only</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6318" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6318"></td>
        <td id="LC6318" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">in part. They studied natural forms, as did, indeed, Bellini in the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6319" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6319"></td>
        <td id="LC6319" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Venetian school; they learned something of perspective, air, tree</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6320" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6320"></td>
        <td id="LC6320" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">anatomy, and the appearance of water; but no Dutch painter of</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6321" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6321"></td>
        <td id="LC6321" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">landscape in the seventeenth century grasped the full color of Holland</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6322" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6322"></td>
        <td id="LC6322" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">or painted its many varied lights. They indulged in a meagre</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6323" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6323"></td>
        <td id="LC6323" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">conventional palette of grays, greens, and browns, whereas Holland is</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6324" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6324"></td>
        <td id="LC6324" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">full of brilliant hues.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6325" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6325"></td>
        <td id="LC6325" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6326" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6326"></td>
        <td id="LC6326" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">[Illustration: FIG. 84.--HOBBEMA. THE WATER-WHEEL. AMSTERDAM MUS.]</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6327" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6327"></td>
        <td id="LC6327" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6328" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6328"></td>
        <td id="LC6328" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Van Goyen (1596-1656) was one of the earliest of the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6329" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6329"></td>
        <td id="LC6329" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">seventeenth-century landscapists. In subject he was fond of the Dutch</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6330" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6330"></td>
        <td id="LC6330" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">bays, harbors, rivers, and canals with shipping, windmills, and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6331" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6331"></td>
        <td id="LC6331" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">houses. His sky line was generally given low, his water silvery, and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6332" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6332"></td>
        <td id="LC6332" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">his sky misty and luminous with bursts of white light. In color he</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6333" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6333"></td>
        <td id="LC6333" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">was subdued, and in perspective quite cunning at times. Salomon van</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6334" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6334"></td>
        <td id="LC6334" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Ruisdael (1600?-1670) was his follower, if not his pupil. He had the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6335" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6335"></td>
        <td id="LC6335" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">same sobriety of color as his master, and was a mannered and prosaic</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6336" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6336"></td>
        <td id="LC6336" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">painter in details, such as leaves and tree-branches. In composition</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6337" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6337"></td>
        <td id="LC6337" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">he was good, but his art had only a slight basis upon reality, though</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6338" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6338"></td>
        <td id="LC6338" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">it looks to be realistic at first sight. He had a formula for doing</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6339" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6339"></td>
        <td id="LC6339" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">landscape which he varied only in a slight way, and this</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6340" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6340"></td>
        <td id="LC6340" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">conventionality ran through all his work. Molyn (1600?-1661) was a</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6341" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6341"></td>
        <td id="LC6341" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">painter who showed limited truth to nature in flat and hilly</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6342" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6342"></td>
        <td id="LC6342" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">landscapes, transparent skies, and warm coloring. His extant works are</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6343" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6343"></td>
        <td id="LC6343" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">few in number. Wynants (1615?-1679?) was more of a realist in natural</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6344" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6344"></td>
        <td id="LC6344" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">appearance than any of the others, a man who evidently studied</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6345" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6345"></td>
        <td id="LC6345" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">directly from nature in details of vegetation, plants, trees, roads,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6346" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6346"></td>
        <td id="LC6346" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">grasses, and the like. Most of the figures and animals in his</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6347" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6347"></td>
        <td id="LC6347" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">landscapes were painted by other hands. He himself was a pure</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6348" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6348"></td>
        <td id="LC6348" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">landscape-painter, excelling in light and aerial perspective, but not</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6349" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6349"></td>
        <td id="LC6349" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">remarkable in color. Van der Neer (1603-1677) and Everdingen</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6350" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6350"></td>
        <td id="LC6350" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">(1621?-1675) were two other contemporary painters of merit.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6351" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6351"></td>
        <td id="LC6351" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6352" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6352"></td>
        <td id="LC6352" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">The best landscapist following the first men of the century was Jacob</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6353" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6353"></td>
        <td id="LC6353" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">van Ruisdael (1625?-1682), the nephew of Salomon van Ruisdael. He is</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6354" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6354"></td>
        <td id="LC6354" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">put down, with perhaps unnecessary emphasis, as the greatest</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6355" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6355"></td>
        <td id="LC6355" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">landscape-painter of the Dutch school. He was undoubtedly the equal of</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6356" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6356"></td>
        <td id="LC6356" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">any of his time, though not so near to nature, perhaps, as Hobbema. He</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6357" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6357"></td>
        <td id="LC6357" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">was a man of imagination, who at first pictured the Dutch country</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6358" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6358"></td>
        <td id="LC6358" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">about Haarlem, and afterward took up with the romantic landscape of</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6359" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6359"></td>
        <td id="LC6359" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Van Everdingen. This landscape bears a resemblance to the Norwegian</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6360" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6360"></td>
        <td id="LC6360" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">country, abounding, as it does, in mountains, heavy dark woods, and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6361" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6361"></td>
        <td id="LC6361" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">rushing torrents. There is considerable poetry in its composition, its</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6362" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6362"></td>
        <td id="LC6362" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">gloomy skies, and darkened lights. It is mournful, suggestive, wild,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6363" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6363"></td>
        <td id="LC6363" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">usually unpeopled. There was much of the methodical in its putting</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6364" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6364"></td>
        <td id="LC6364" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">together, and in color it was cold, and limited to a few tones. Many</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6365" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6365"></td>
        <td id="LC6365" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">of Ruisdael&#39;s works have darkened through time. Little is known about</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6366" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6366"></td>
        <td id="LC6366" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">the painter&#39;s life except that he was not appreciated in his own time</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6367" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6367"></td>
        <td id="LC6367" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">and died in the almshouse.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6368" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6368"></td>
        <td id="LC6368" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6369" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6369"></td>
        <td id="LC6369" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Hobbema (1638?-1709) was probably the pupil of Jacob van Ruisdael, and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6370" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6370"></td>
        <td id="LC6370" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">ranks with him, if not above him, in seventeenth-century landscape</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6371" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6371"></td>
        <td id="LC6371" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">painting. Ruisdael hardly ever painted sunlight, whereas Hobbema</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6372" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6372"></td>
        <td id="LC6372" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">rather affected it in quiet wood-scenes or roadways with little pools</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6373" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6373"></td>
        <td id="LC6373" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">of water and a mill. He was a freer man with the brush than Ruisdael,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6374" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6374"></td>
        <td id="LC6374" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">and knew more about the natural appearance of trees, skies, and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6375" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6375"></td>
        <td id="LC6375" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">lights; but, like his master, his view of nature found no favor in his</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6376" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6376"></td>
        <td id="LC6376" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">own land. Most of his work is in England, where it had not a little to</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6377" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6377"></td>
        <td id="LC6377" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">do with influencing such painters as Constable and others at the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6378" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6378"></td>
        <td id="LC6378" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">beginning of the nineteenth century.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6379" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6379"></td>
        <td id="LC6379" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6380" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6380"></td>
        <td id="LC6380" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">[Illustration: FIG. 85.--ISRAELS. ALONE IN THE WORLD.]</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6381" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6381"></td>
        <td id="LC6381" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6382" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6382"></td>
        <td id="LC6382" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">LANDSCAPE WITH CATTLE: Here we meet with Wouverman (1619-1668), a</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6383" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6383"></td>
        <td id="LC6383" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">painter of horses, cavalry, battles, and riding parties placed in</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6384" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6384"></td>
        <td id="LC6384" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">landscape. His landscape is bright and his horses are spirited in</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6385" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6385"></td>
        <td id="LC6385" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">action. There is some mannerism apparent in his reiterated</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6386" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6386"></td>
        <td id="LC6386" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">concentration of light on a white horse, and some repetition in his</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6387" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6387"></td>
        <td id="LC6387" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">canvases, of which there are many; but on the whole he was an</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6388" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6388"></td>
        <td id="LC6388" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">interesting, if smooth and neat painter. Paul Potter (1625-1654)</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6389" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6389"></td>
        <td id="LC6389" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">hardly merited his great repute. He was a harsh, exact recorder of</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6390" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6390"></td>
        <td id="LC6390" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">facts, often tin-like or woodeny in his cattle, and not in any way</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6391" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6391"></td>
        <td id="LC6391" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">remarkable in his landscapes, least of all in their composition. The</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6392" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6392"></td>
        <td id="LC6392" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Young Bull at the Hague is an ambitious piece of drawing, but is not</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6393" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6393"></td>
        <td id="LC6393" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">successful in color, light, or _ensemble_. It is a brittle work all</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6394" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6394"></td>
        <td id="LC6394" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">through, and not nearly so good as some smaller things in the National</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6395" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6395"></td>
        <td id="LC6395" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Gallery London, and in the Louvre. Adrien van de Velde (1635?-1672)</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6396" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6396"></td>
        <td id="LC6396" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">was short-lived, like Potter, but managed to do a prodigious amount</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6397" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6397"></td>
        <td id="LC6397" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">of work, showing cattle and figures in landscape with much technical</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6398" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6398"></td>
        <td id="LC6398" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">ability and good feeling. He was particularly good in composition and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6399" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6399"></td>
        <td id="LC6399" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">the subtle gradation of neutral tints. A little of the Italian</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6400" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6400"></td>
        <td id="LC6400" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">influence appeared in his work, and with the men who came with him and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6401" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6401"></td>
        <td id="LC6401" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">after him the Italian imitation became very pronounced. Aelbert Cuyp</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6402" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6402"></td>
        <td id="LC6402" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">(1620-1691) was a many-sided painter, adopting at various times</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6403" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6403"></td>
        <td id="LC6403" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">different styles, but was enough of a genius to be himself always. He</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6404" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6404"></td>
        <td id="LC6404" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">is best known to us, perhaps, by his yellow sunlight effects along</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6405" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6405"></td>
        <td id="LC6405" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">rivers, with cattle in the foreground, though he painted still-life,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6406" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6406"></td>
        <td id="LC6406" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">and even portraits and marines. In composing a group he was knowing,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6407" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6407"></td>
        <td id="LC6407" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">recording natural effects with power; in light and atmosphere he was</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6408" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6408"></td>
        <td id="LC6408" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">one of the best of his time, and in texture and color refined, and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6409" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6409"></td>
        <td id="LC6409" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">frequently brilliant. Both (1610-1650?), Berchem (1620-1683), Du</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6410" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6410"></td>
        <td id="LC6410" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Jardin (1622?-1678), followed the Italian tradition of Claude Lorrain,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6411" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6411"></td>
        <td id="LC6411" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">producing semi-classic landscapes, never very convincing in their</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6412" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6412"></td>
        <td id="LC6412" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">originality. Van der Heyden (1637-1712), should be mentioned as an</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6413" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6413"></td>
        <td id="LC6413" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">excellent, if minute, painter of architecture with remarkable</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6414" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6414"></td>
        <td id="LC6414" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">atmospheric effects.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6415" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6415"></td>
        <td id="LC6415" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6416" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6416"></td>
        <td id="LC6416" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">MARINE AND STILL-LIFE PAINTERS: There were two pre-eminent marine</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6417" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6417"></td>
        <td id="LC6417" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">painters in this seventeenth century, Willem van de Velde (1633-1707)</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6418" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6418"></td>
        <td id="LC6418" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">and Backhuisen (1631-1708). The sea was not an unusual subject with</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6419" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6419"></td>
        <td id="LC6419" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">the Dutch landscapists. Van Goyen, Simon de Vlieger (1601?-1660?),</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6420" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6420"></td>
        <td id="LC6420" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Cuyp, Willem van de Velde the Elder (1611?-1693), all employed it; but</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6421" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6421"></td>
        <td id="LC6421" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">it was Van de Velde the Younger who really stood at the head of the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6422" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6422"></td>
        <td id="LC6422" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">marine painters. He knew his subject thoroughly, having been well</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6423" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6423"></td>
        <td id="LC6423" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">grounded in it by his father and De Vlieger, so that the painting of</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6424" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6424"></td>
        <td id="LC6424" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">the Dutch fleets and harbors was a part of his nature. He preferred</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6425" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6425"></td>
        <td id="LC6425" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">the quiet haven to the open sea. Smooth water, calm skies, silvery</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6426" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6426"></td>
        <td id="LC6426" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">light, and boats lying listlessly at anchor with drooping sails, made</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6427" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6427"></td>
        <td id="LC6427" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">up his usual subject. The color was almost always in a key of silver</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6428" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6428"></td>
        <td id="LC6428" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">and gray, very charming in its harmony and serenity, but a little</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6429" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6429"></td>
        <td id="LC6429" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">thin. Both he and his father went to England and entered the service</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6430" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6430"></td>
        <td id="LC6430" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">of the English king, and thereafter did English fleets rather than</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6431" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6431"></td>
        <td id="LC6431" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Dutch ones. Backhuisen was quite the reverse of Van de Velde in</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6432" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6432"></td>
        <td id="LC6432" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">preferring the tempest to the calm of the sea. He also used more</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6433" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6433"></td>
        <td id="LC6433" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">brilliant and varied colors, but he was not so happy in harmony as Van</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6434" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6434"></td>
        <td id="LC6434" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">de Velde. There was often dryness in his handling, and something too</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6435" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6435"></td>
        <td id="LC6435" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">much of the theatrical in his wrecks on rocky shores.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6436" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6436"></td>
        <td id="LC6436" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6437" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6437"></td>
        <td id="LC6437" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">The still-life painters of Holland were all of them rather petty in</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6438" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6438"></td>
        <td id="LC6438" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">their emphasis of details such as figures on table-covers, water-drops</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6439" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6439"></td>
        <td id="LC6439" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">on flowers, and fur on rabbits. It was labored work with little of the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6440" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6440"></td>
        <td id="LC6440" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">art spirit about it, except as the composition showed good masses. A</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6441" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6441"></td>
        <td id="LC6441" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">number of these painters gained celebrity in their day by their</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6442" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6442"></td>
        <td id="LC6442" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">microscopic labor over fruits, flowers, and the like, but they have no</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6443" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6443"></td>
        <td id="LC6443" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">great rank at the present time. Jan van Heem (1600?1684?) was perhaps</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6444" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6444"></td>
        <td id="LC6444" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">the best painter of flowers among them. Van Huysum (1682-1749)</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6445" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6445"></td>
        <td id="LC6445" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">succeeded with the same subject beyond his deserts. Hondecoeter</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6446" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6446"></td>
        <td id="LC6446" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">(1636-1695) was a unique painter of poultry; Weenix (1640-1719) and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6447" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6447"></td>
        <td id="LC6447" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Van Aelst (1620-1679), of dead game; Kalf (1630?-1693), of pots, pans,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6448" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6448"></td>
        <td id="LC6448" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">dishes, and vegetables.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6449" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6449"></td>
        <td id="LC6449" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6450" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6450"></td>
        <td id="LC6450" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">EIGHTEENTH CENTURY: This was a period of decadence during which there</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6451" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6451"></td>
        <td id="LC6451" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">was no originality worth speaking about among the Dutch painters.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6452" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6452"></td>
        <td id="LC6452" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Realism in minute features was carried to the extreme, and imitation</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6453" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6453"></td>
        <td id="LC6453" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">of the early men took the place of invention. Everything was</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6454" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6454"></td>
        <td id="LC6454" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">prettified and elaborated until there was a porcelain smoothness and a</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6455" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6455"></td>
        <td id="LC6455" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">photographic exactness inconsistent with true art. Adriaan van der</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6456" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6456"></td>
        <td id="LC6456" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Werff (1659-1722), and Philip van Dyck (1683-1753) with their &quot;ideal&quot;</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6457" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6457"></td>
        <td id="LC6457" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">inanities are typical of the century&#39;s art. There was nothing to</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6458" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6458"></td>
        <td id="LC6458" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">commend it. The lowest point of affectation had been reached.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6459" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6459"></td>
        <td id="LC6459" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6460" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6460"></td>
        <td id="LC6460" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">NINETEENTH CENTURY: The Dutch painters, unlike the Belgians, have</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6461" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6461"></td>
        <td id="LC6461" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">almost always been true to their own traditions and their own country.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6462" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6462"></td>
        <td id="LC6462" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Even in decadence the most of them feebly followed their own painters</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6463" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6463"></td>
        <td id="LC6463" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">rather than those of Italy and France, and in the early nineteenth</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6464" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6464"></td>
        <td id="LC6464" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">century they were not affected by the French classicism of David.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6465" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6465"></td>
        <td id="LC6465" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Later on there came into vogue an art that had some affinity with that</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6466" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6466"></td>
        <td id="LC6466" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">of Millet and Courbet in France. It was the Dutch version of modern</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6467" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6467"></td>
        <td id="LC6467" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">sentiment about the laboring classes, founded on the modern life of</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6468" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6468"></td>
        <td id="LC6468" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Holland, yet in reality a continuation of the style or _genre_</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6469" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6469"></td>
        <td id="LC6469" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">practised by the early Dutchmen. Israels (1824-) is a revival or a</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6470" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6470"></td>
        <td id="LC6470" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">survival of Rembrandtesque methods with a sentiment and feeling akin</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6471" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6471"></td>
        <td id="LC6471" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">to the French Millet. He deals almost exclusively with peasant life,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6472" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6472"></td>
        <td id="LC6472" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">showing fisher-folk and the like in their cottage interiors, at the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6473" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6473"></td>
        <td id="LC6473" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">table, or before the fire, with good effects of light, atmosphere, and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6474" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6474"></td>
        <td id="LC6474" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">much pathos. Technically he is rather labored and heavy in handling,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6475" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6475"></td>
        <td id="LC6475" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">but usually effective with sombre color in giving the unity of a</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6476" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6476"></td>
        <td id="LC6476" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">scene. Artz (1837-1890) considered himself in measure a follower of</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6477" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6477"></td>
        <td id="LC6477" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Israels, though he never studied under him. His pictures in subject</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6478" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6478"></td>
        <td id="LC6478" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">are like those of Israels, but without the depth of the latter.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6479" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6479"></td>
        <td id="LC6479" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Blommers (1845-) is another peasant painter who follows Israels at a</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6480" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6480"></td>
        <td id="LC6480" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">distance, and Neuhuys (1844-) shows a similar style of work. Bosboom</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6481" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6481"></td>
        <td id="LC6481" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">(1817-1891) excelled in representing interiors, showing, with much</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6482" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6482"></td>
        <td id="LC6482" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">pictorial effect, the light, color, shadow, and feeling of space and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6483" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6483"></td>
        <td id="LC6483" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">air in large cathedrals.</td>
