      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6484" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6484"></td>
        <td id="LC6484" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6485" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6485"></td>
        <td id="LC6485" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">[Illustration: FIG. 86.--MAUVE. SHEEP.]</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6486" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6486"></td>
        <td id="LC6486" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6487" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6487"></td>
        <td id="LC6487" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">The brothers Maris have made a distinct impression on modern Dutch</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6488" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6488"></td>
        <td id="LC6488" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">art, and, strange enough, each in a different way from the others.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6489" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6489"></td>
        <td id="LC6489" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">James Maris (1837-) studied at Paris, and is remarkable for fine,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6490" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6490"></td>
        <td id="LC6490" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">vigorous views of canals, towns, and landscapes. He is broad in</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6491" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6491"></td>
        <td id="LC6491" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">handling, rather bleak in coloring, and excels in fine luminous skies</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6492" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6492"></td>
        <td id="LC6492" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">and voyaging clouds. Matthew Maris (1835-), Parisian trained like his</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6493" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6493"></td>
        <td id="LC6493" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">brother, lives in London, where little is seen of his work. He paints</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6494" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6494"></td>
        <td id="LC6494" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">for himself and his friends, and is rather melancholy and mystical in</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6495" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6495"></td>
        <td id="LC6495" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">his art. He is a recorder of visions and dreams rather than the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6496" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6496"></td>
        <td id="LC6496" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">substantial things of the earth, but always with richness of color and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6497" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6497"></td>
        <td id="LC6497" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">a fine decorative feeling. Willem Maris (1839-), sometimes called the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6498" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6498"></td>
        <td id="LC6498" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">&quot;Silvery Maris,&quot; is a portrayer of cattle and landscape in warm</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6499" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6499"></td>
        <td id="LC6499" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">sunlight and haze with a charm of color and tone often suggestive of</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6500" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6500"></td>
        <td id="LC6500" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Corot. Jongkind (1819-1891) stands by himself, Mesdag (1831-) is a</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6501" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6501"></td>
        <td id="LC6501" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">fine painter of marines and sea-shores, and Mauve (1838-1888), a</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6502" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6502"></td>
        <td id="LC6502" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">cattle and sheep painter, with nice sentiment and tonality, whose</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6503" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6503"></td>
        <td id="LC6503" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">renown is just now somewhat disproportionate to his artistic ability.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6504" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6504"></td>

      <tr>
        <td id="L6587" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6587"></td>
        <td id="LC6587" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     Jahrhunderts_; Reber, _Geschichte der neueren Deutschen</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6588" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6588"></td>
        <td id="LC6588" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     Kunst_; Riegel, _Deutsche Kunststudien_; Rosenberg, _Die</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6589" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6589"></td>
        <td id="LC6589" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     Berliner Malerschule_; Rosenberg, _Sebald und Barthel</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6590" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6590"></td>
        <td id="LC6590" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     Beham_; Rumohr, _Hans Holbein der Jungere_; Sandrart,</td>

      <tr>
        <td id="L6591" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6591"></td>
        <td id="LC6591" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     _Teutsche Akademie der Edlen Bau, Bild-und Malerey-Kunste_;</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6592" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6592"></td>
        <td id="LC6592" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     Schuchardt, _Lucas Cranach&#39;s Leben_; Thausig, _Albert Durer,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6593" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6593"></td>
        <td id="LC6593" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     His Life and Works_; Waagen, _Kunstwerke und Kunstler in</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6594" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6594"></td>
        <td id="LC6594" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     Deutschland_; E. aus&#39;m Weerth, _Wandmalereien des</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6595" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6595"></td>
        <td id="LC6595" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     Mittelalters in den Rheinlanden_; Wessely, _Adolph Menzel_;</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6596" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6596"></td>
        <td id="LC6596" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     Woltmann, _Holbein and his Time_; Woltmann, _Geschichte der</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6597" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6597"></td>
        <td id="LC6597" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">     Deutschen Kunst im Elsass_; Wurtzbach, _Martin Schongauer_.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6598" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6598"></td>
        <td id="LC6598" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6599" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6599"></td>
        <td id="LC6599" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6600" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6600"></td>
        <td id="LC6600" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">EARLY GERMAN PAINTING: The Teutonic lands, like almost all of the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6601" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6601"></td>
        <td id="LC6601" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">countries of Europe, received their first art impulse from</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6602" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6602"></td>
        <td id="LC6602" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Christianity through Italy. The centre of the faith was at Rome, and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6603" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6603"></td>
        <td id="LC6603" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">from there the influence in art spread west and north, and in each</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6604" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6604"></td>
        <td id="LC6604" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">land it was modified by local peculiarities of type and temperament.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6605" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6605"></td>
        <td id="LC6605" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">In Germany, even in the early days, though Christianity was the theme</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6606" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6606"></td>
        <td id="LC6606" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">of early illuminations, miniatures, and the like, and though there was</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6607" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6607"></td>
        <td id="LC6607" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">a traditional form reaching back to Italy and Byzantium, yet under it</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6608" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6608"></td>
        <td id="LC6608" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">was the Teutonic type--the material, awkward, rather coarse Germanic</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6609" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6609"></td>
        <td id="LC6609" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">point of view. The wish to realize native surroundings was apparent</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6610" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6610"></td>
        <td id="LC6610" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">from the beginning.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6611" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6611"></td>
        <td id="LC6611" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6612" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6612"></td>
        <td id="LC6612" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">It is probable that the earliest painting in Germany took the form of</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6613" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6613"></td>
        <td id="LC6613" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">illuminations. At what date it first appeared is unknown. In</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6614" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6614"></td>
        <td id="LC6614" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">wall-painting a poor quality of work was executed in the churches as</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6615" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6615"></td>
        <td id="LC6615" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">early as the ninth century, and probably earlier. The oldest now</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6616" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6616"></td>
        <td id="LC6616" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">extant are those at Oberzell, dating back to the last part of the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6617" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6617"></td>
        <td id="LC6617" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">tenth century. Better examples are seen in the Lower Church of</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6618" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6618"></td>
        <td id="LC6618" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Schwarzrheindorf, of the twelfth century, and still better in the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6619" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6619"></td>
        <td id="LC6619" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">choir and transept of the Brunswick cathedral, ascribed to the early</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6620" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6620"></td>
        <td id="LC6620" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">thirteenth century.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6621" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6621"></td>
        <td id="LC6621" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6622" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6622"></td>
        <td id="LC6622" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">[Illustration: FIG. 87.--LOCHNER. STS. JOHN, CATHERINE, AND MATTHEW.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6623" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6623"></td>
        <td id="LC6623" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">NAT. GAL. LONDON.]</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6624" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6624"></td>
        <td id="LC6624" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6625" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6625"></td>
        <td id="LC6625" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">All of these works have an archaic appearance about them, but they</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6626" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6626"></td>
        <td id="LC6626" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">are better in composition and drawing than the productions of Italy</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6627" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6627"></td>
        <td id="LC6627" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">and Byzantium at that time. It is likely that all the German churches</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6628" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6628"></td>
        <td id="LC6628" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">at this time were decorated, but most of the paintings have been</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6629" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6629"></td>
        <td id="LC6629" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">destroyed. The usual method was to cover the walls and wooden ceilings</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6630" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6630"></td>
        <td id="LC6630" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">with blue grounds, and upon these to place figures surrounded by</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6631" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6631"></td>
        <td id="LC6631" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">architectural ornaments. Stained glass was also used extensively.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6632" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6632"></td>
        <td id="LC6632" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Panel painting seems to have come into existence before the thirteenth</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6633" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6633"></td>
        <td id="LC6633" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">century (whether developed from miniature or wall-painting is</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6634" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6634"></td>
        <td id="LC6634" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">unknown), and was used for altar decorations. The panels were done in</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6635" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6635"></td>
        <td id="LC6635" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">tempera with figures in light colors upon gold grounds. The</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6636" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6636"></td>
        <td id="LC6636" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">spirituality of the age with a mingling of northern sentiment appeared</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6637" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6637"></td>
        <td id="LC6637" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">in the figure. This figure was at times graceful, and again awkward</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6638" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6638"></td>
        <td id="LC6638" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">and archaic, according to the place of production and the influence of</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6639" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6639"></td>
        <td id="LC6639" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">either France or Italy. The oldest panels extant are from the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6640" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6640"></td>
        <td id="LC6640" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Wiesenkirche at Soest, now in the Berlin Museum. They do not date</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6641" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6641"></td>
        <td id="LC6641" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">before the thirteenth century.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6642" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6642"></td>
        <td id="LC6642" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6643" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6643"></td>
        <td id="LC6643" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">FOURTEENTH AND FIFTEENTH CENTURIES: In the fourteenth century the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6644" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6644"></td>
        <td id="LC6644" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">influence of France began to show strongly in willowy figures, long</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6645" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6645"></td>
        <td id="LC6645" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">flowing draperies, and sentimental poses. The artists along the Rhine</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6646" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6646"></td>
        <td id="LC6646" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">showed this more than those in the provinces to the east, where a</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6647" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6647"></td>
        <td id="LC6647" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">ruder if freer art appeared. The best panel-painting of the time was</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6648" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6648"></td>
        <td id="LC6648" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">done at Cologne, where we meet with the name of the first painter,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6649" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6649"></td>
        <td id="LC6649" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Meister Wilhelm, and where a school was established usually known as</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6650" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6650"></td>
        <td id="LC6650" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6651" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6651"></td>
        <td id="LC6651" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6652" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6652"></td>
        <td id="LC6652" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">SCHOOL OF COLOGNE: This school probably got its sentimental</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6653" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6653"></td>
        <td id="LC6653" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">inclination, shown in slight forms and tender expression, from France,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6654" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6654"></td>
        <td id="LC6654" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">but derived much of its technic from the Netherlands. Stephen Lochner,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6655" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6655"></td>
        <td id="LC6655" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">or Meister Stephen, (fl. 1450) leaned toward the Flemish methods, and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6656" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6656"></td>
        <td id="LC6656" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">in his celebrated picture, the Madonna of the Rose Garden, in the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6657" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6657"></td>
        <td id="LC6657" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Cologne Museum, there is an indication of this; but there is also an</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6658" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6658"></td>
        <td id="LC6658" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">individuality showing the growth of German independence in painting.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6659" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6659"></td>
        <td id="LC6659" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">The figures of his Dombild have little manliness or power, but</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6660" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6660"></td>
        <td id="LC6660" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">considerable grace, pathos, and religious feeling. They are not</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6661" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6661"></td>
        <td id="LC6661" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">abstract types but the spiritualized people of the country in native</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6662" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6662"></td>
        <td id="LC6662" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">costumes, with much gold, jewelry, and armor. Gold was used instead of</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6663" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6663"></td>
        <td id="LC6663" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">a landscape background, and the foreground was spattered with flowers</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6664" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6664"></td>
        <td id="LC6664" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">and leaves. The outlines are rather hard, and none of the aerial</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6665" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6665"></td>
        <td id="LC6665" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">perspective of the Flemings is given. After a time French sentiment</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6666" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6666"></td>
        <td id="LC6666" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">was still further encroached upon by Flemish realism, as shown in the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6667" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6667"></td>
        <td id="LC6667" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">works of the Master of the Lyversberg Passion (fl. about 1463-1480),</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6668" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6668"></td>
        <td id="LC6668" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">to be seen in the Cologne Museum.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6669" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6669"></td>
        <td id="LC6669" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6670" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6670"></td>
        <td id="LC6670" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">[Illustration: FIG. 88.--WOLGEMUT. CRUCIFIXION. MUNICH.]</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6671" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6671"></td>
        <td id="LC6671" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6672" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6672"></td>
        <td id="LC6672" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">BOHEMIAN SCHOOL: It was not on the Lower Rhine alone that German</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6673" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6673"></td>
        <td id="LC6673" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">painting was practised. The Bohemian school, located near Prague,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6674" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6674"></td>
        <td id="LC6674" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">flourished for a short time in the fourteenth century, under Charles</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6675" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6675"></td>
        <td id="LC6675" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">IV., with Theodorich of Prague (fl. 1348-1378), Wurmser, and Kunz, as</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6676" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6676"></td>
        <td id="LC6676" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">the chief masters. Their art was quite the reverse of the Cologne</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6677" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6677"></td>
        <td id="LC6677" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">painters. It was heavy, clumsy, bony, awkward. If more original it was</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6678" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6678"></td>
        <td id="LC6678" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">less graceful, not so pathetic, not so religious. Sentiment was</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6679" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6679"></td>
        <td id="LC6679" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">slurred through a harsh attempt at realism, and the religious subject</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6680" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6680"></td>
        <td id="LC6680" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">met with something of a check in the romantic mediaeval chivalric</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6681" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6681"></td>
        <td id="LC6681" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">theme, painted quite as often on the castle wall as the scriptural</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6682" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6682"></td>
        <td id="LC6682" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">theme on the church wall. After the close of the fourteenth century</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6683" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6683"></td>
        <td id="LC6683" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">wall-painting began to die out in favor of panel pictures.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6684" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6684"></td>
        <td id="LC6684" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6685" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6685"></td>
        <td id="LC6685" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">NUREMBERG SCHOOL: Half-way between the sentiment of Cologne and the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6686" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6686"></td>
        <td id="LC6686" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">realism of Prague stood the early school of Nuremberg, with no known</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6687" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6687"></td>
        <td id="LC6687" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">painter at its head. Its chief work, the Imhof altar-piece, shows,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6688" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6688"></td>
        <td id="LC6688" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">however, that the Nuremberg masters of the early and middle fifteenth</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6689" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6689"></td>
        <td id="LC6689" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">century were between eastern and western influences. They inclined to</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6690" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6690"></td>
        <td id="LC6690" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">the graceful swaying figure, following more the sculpture of the time</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6691" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6691"></td>
        <td id="LC6691" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">than the Cologne type.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6692" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6692"></td>
        <td id="LC6692" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6693" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6693"></td>
        <td id="LC6693" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">FIFTEENTH AND SIXTEENTH CENTURIES: German art, if begun in the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6694" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6694"></td>
        <td id="LC6694" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">fourteenth century, hardly showed any depth or breadth until the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6695" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6695"></td>
        <td id="LC6695" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">fifteenth century, and no real individual strength until the sixteenth</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6696" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6696"></td>
        <td id="LC6696" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">century. It lagged behind the other countries of Europe and produced</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6697" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6697"></td>
        <td id="LC6697" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">the cramped archaic altar-piece. Then when printing was invented the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6698" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6698"></td>
        <td id="LC6698" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">painter-engraver came into existence. He was a man who painted panels,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6699" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6699"></td>
        <td id="LC6699" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">but found his largest audience through the circulation of engravings.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6700" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6700"></td>
        <td id="LC6700" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">The two kinds of arts being produced by the one man led to much</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6701" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6701"></td>
        <td id="LC6701" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">detailed line work with the brush. Engraving is an influence to be</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6702" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6702"></td>
        <td id="LC6702" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">borne in mind in examining the painting of this period.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6703" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6703"></td>
        <td id="LC6703" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6704" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6704"></td>
        <td id="LC6704" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">[Illustration: FIG. 89.--DUeRER. PRAYING VIRGIN. AUGSBURG.]</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6705" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6705"></td>
        <td id="LC6705" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6706" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6706"></td>
        <td id="LC6706" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">FRANCONIAN SCHOOL: Nuremberg was the centre of this school, and its</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6707" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6707"></td>
        <td id="LC6707" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">most famous early master was Wolgemut (1434-1519), though Plydenwurff</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6708" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6708"></td>
        <td id="LC6708" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">is the first-named painter. After the latter&#39;s death Wolgemut married</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6709" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6709"></td>
        <td id="LC6709" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">his widow and became the head of the school. His paintings were</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6710" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6710"></td>
        <td id="LC6710" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">chiefly altar-pieces, in which the figures were rather lank and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6711" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6711"></td>
        <td id="LC6711" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">narrow-shouldered, with sharp outlines, indicative perhaps of the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6712" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6712"></td>
        <td id="LC6712" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">influence of wood-engraving, in which he was much interested. There</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6713" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6713"></td>
        <td id="LC6713" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">was, however, in his work an advance in characterization, nobility of</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6714" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6714"></td>
        <td id="LC6714" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">expression, and quiet dignity, and it was his good fortune to be the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6715" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6715"></td>
        <td id="LC6715" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">master of one of the most thoroughly original painters of all the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6716" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6716"></td>
        <td id="LC6716" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">German schools--Albrecht Duerer (1471-1528).</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6717" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6717"></td>
        <td id="LC6717" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6718" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6718"></td>
        <td id="LC6718" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">With Duerer and Holbein German art reached its apogee in the first half</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6719" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6719"></td>
        <td id="LC6719" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">of the sixteenth century, yet their work was not different in spirit</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6720" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6720"></td>
        <td id="LC6720" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">from that of their predecessors. Painting simply developed and became</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6721" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6721"></td>
        <td id="LC6721" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">forceful and expressive technically without abandoning its early</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6722" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6722"></td>
        <td id="LC6722" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">character. There is in Duerer a naive awkwardness of figure, some</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6723" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6723"></td>
        <td id="LC6723" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">angularity of line, strain of pose, and in composition oftentimes</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6724" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6724"></td>
        <td id="LC6724" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">huddling and overloading of the scene with details. There is not that</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6725" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6725"></td>
        <td id="LC6725" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">largeness which seemed native to his Italian contemporaries. He was</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6726" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6726"></td>
        <td id="LC6726" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">hampered by that German exactness, which found its best expression in</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6727" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6727"></td>
        <td id="LC6727" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">engraving, and which, though unsuited to painting, nevertheless crept</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6728" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6728"></td>
        <td id="LC6728" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">into it. Within these limitations Duerer produced the typical art of</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6729" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6729"></td>
        <td id="LC6729" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Germany in the Renaissance time--an art more attractive for the charm</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6730" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6730"></td>
        <td id="LC6730" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">and beauty of its parts than for its unity, or its general impression.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6731" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6731"></td>
        <td id="LC6731" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Duerer was a travelled man, visited Italy and the Netherlands, and,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6732" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6732"></td>
        <td id="LC6732" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">though he always remained a German in art, yet he picked up some</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6733" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6733"></td>
        <td id="LC6733" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Italian methods from Bellini and Mantegna that are faintly apparent in</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6734" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6734"></td>
        <td id="LC6734" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">some of his works. In subject he was almost exclusively religious,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6735" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6735"></td>
        <td id="LC6735" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">painting the altar-piece with infinite care upon wooden panel, canvas,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6736" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6736"></td>
        <td id="LC6736" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">or parchment. He never worked in fresco, preferring oil and tempera.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6737" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6737"></td>
        <td id="LC6737" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">In drawing he was often harsh and faulty, in draperies cramped at</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6738" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6738"></td>
        <td id="LC6738" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">times, and then, again, as in the Apostle panels at Munich, very</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6739" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6739"></td>
        <td id="LC6739" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">broad, and effective. Many of his pictures show a hard, dry brush, and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6740" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6740"></td>
        <td id="LC6740" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">a few, again, are so free and mellow that they look as though done by</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6741" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6741"></td>
        <td id="LC6741" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">another hand. He was usually minute in detail, especially in such</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6742" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6742"></td>
        <td id="LC6742" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">features as hair, cloth, flesh. His portraits were uneven and not his</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6743" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6743"></td>
        <td id="LC6743" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">best productions. He was too close a scrutinizer of the part and not</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6744" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6744"></td>
        <td id="LC6744" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">enough of an observer of the whole for good portraiture. Indeed, that</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6745" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6745"></td>
        <td id="LC6745" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">is the criticism to be made upon all his work. He was an exquisite</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6746" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6746"></td>
        <td id="LC6746" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">realist of certain features, but not always of the _ensemble_.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6747" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6747"></td>
        <td id="LC6747" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Nevertheless he holds first rank in the German art of the Renaissance,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6748" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6748"></td>
        <td id="LC6748" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">not only on account of his technical ability, but also because of his</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6749" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6749"></td>
        <td id="LC6749" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">imagination, sincerity, and striking originality.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6750" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6750"></td>
        <td id="LC6750" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6751" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6751"></td>
        <td id="LC6751" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">[Illustration: FIG. 90.--HOLBEIN THE YOUNGER. PORTRAIT. HAGUE MUS.]</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6752" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6752"></td>
        <td id="LC6752" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6753" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6753"></td>
        <td id="LC6753" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Duerer&#39;s influence was wide-spread throughout Germany, especially in</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6754" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6754"></td>
        <td id="LC6754" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">engraving, of which he was a master. In painting Schaeufelin</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6755" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6755"></td>
        <td id="LC6755" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">(1490?-1540?) was probably his apprentice, and in his work followed</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6756" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6756"></td>
        <td id="LC6756" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">the master so closely that many of his works have been attributed to</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6757" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6757"></td>
        <td id="LC6757" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Duerer. This is true in measure of Hans Baldung (1476?-1552?). Hans von</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6758" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6758"></td>
        <td id="LC6758" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Kulmbach (?-1522) was a painter of more than ordinary importance,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6759" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6759"></td>
        <td id="LC6759" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">brilliant in coloring, a follower of Duerer, who was inclined toward</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6760" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6760"></td>
        <td id="LC6760" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Italian methods, an inclination that afterward developed all through</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6761" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6761"></td>
        <td id="LC6761" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">German art. Following Duerer&#39;s formulas came a large number of</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6762" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6762"></td>
        <td id="LC6762" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">so-called &quot;Little Masters&quot; (from the size of their engraved plates),</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6763" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6763"></td>
        <td id="LC6763" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">who were more engravers than painters. Among the more important of</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6764" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6764"></td>
        <td id="LC6764" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">those who were painters as well as engravers were Altdorfer</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6765" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6765"></td>
        <td id="LC6765" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">(1480?-1538), a rival rather than an imitator of Duerer; Barthel Beham</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6766" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6766"></td>
        <td id="LC6766" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">(1502-1540), Sebald Beham (1500-1550), Pencz (1500?-1550), Aldegrever</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6767" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6767"></td>
        <td id="LC6767" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">(1502-1558), and Bink (1490?-1569?).</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6768" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6768"></td>
        <td id="LC6768" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6769" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6769"></td>
        <td id="LC6769" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">SWABIAN SCHOOL: This school includes a number of painters who were</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6770" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6770"></td>
        <td id="LC6770" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">located at different places, like Colmar and Ulm, and later on it</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6771" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6771"></td>
        <td id="LC6771" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">included the Holbeins at Augsburg, who were really the consummation of</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6772" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6772"></td>
        <td id="LC6772" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">the school. In the fifteenth century one of the early leaders was</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6773" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6773"></td>
        <td id="LC6773" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Martin Schoengauer (1446?-1488), at Colmar. He is supposed to have been</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6774" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6774"></td>
        <td id="LC6774" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">a pupil of Roger Van der Weyden, of the Flemish school, and is better</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6775" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6775"></td>
        <td id="LC6775" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">known by his engravings than his paintings, none of the latter being</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6776" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6776"></td>
        <td id="LC6776" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">positively authenticated. He was thoroughly German in his type and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6777" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6777"></td>
        <td id="LC6777" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">treatment, though, perhaps, indebted to the Flemings for his coloring.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6778" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6778"></td>
        <td id="LC6778" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">There was some angularity in his figures and draperies, and a tendency</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6779" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6779"></td>
        <td id="LC6779" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">to get nearer nature and further away from the ecclesiastical and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6780" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6780"></td>
        <td id="LC6780" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">ascetic conception in all that he did.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6781" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6781"></td>
        <td id="LC6781" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6782" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6782"></td>
        <td id="LC6782" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">At Ulm a local school came into existence with Zeitblom (fl.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6783" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6783"></td>
        <td id="LC6783" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">1484-1517), who was probably a pupil of Schuechlin. He had neither</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6784" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6784"></td>
        <td id="LC6784" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Schoengauer&#39;s force nor his fancy, but was a simple, straightforward</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6785" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6785"></td>
        <td id="LC6785" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">painter of one rather strong type. His drawing was not good, except in</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6786" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6786"></td>
        <td id="LC6786" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">the draperies, but he was quite remarkable for the solidity and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6787" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6787"></td>
        <td id="LC6787" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">substance of his painting, considering the age he lived in was given</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6788" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6788"></td>
        <td id="LC6788" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">to hard, thin brush-work. Schaffner (fl. 1500-1535) was another Ulm</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6789" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6789"></td>
        <td id="LC6789" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">painter, a junior to Zeitblom, of whom little is known, save from a</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6790" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6790"></td>
        <td id="LC6790" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">few pictures graceful and free in composition. A recently discovered</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6791" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6791"></td>
        <td id="LC6791" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">man, Bernard Strigel (1461?-1528?) seems to have been excellent in</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6792" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6792"></td>
        <td id="LC6792" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">portraiture.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6793" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6793"></td>
        <td id="LC6793" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6794" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6794"></td>
        <td id="LC6794" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">[Illustration: FIG. 91.--PILOTY. WISE AND FOOLISH VIRGINS.]</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6795" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6795"></td>
        <td id="LC6795" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6796" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6796"></td>
        <td id="LC6796" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">At Augsburg there was still another school, which came into prominence</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6797" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6797"></td>
        <td id="LC6797" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">in the sixteenth century with Burkmair and the Holbeins. It was only a</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6798" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6798"></td>
        <td id="LC6798" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">part of the Swabian school, a concentration of artistic force about</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6799" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6799"></td>
        <td id="LC6799" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Augsburg, which, toward the close of the fifteenth century, had come</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6800" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6800"></td>
        <td id="LC6800" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">into competition with Nuremberg, and rather outranked it in splendor.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6801" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6801"></td>
        <td id="LC6801" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">It was at Augsburg that the Renaissance art in Germany showed in more</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6802" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6802"></td>
        <td id="LC6802" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">restful composition, less angularity, better modelling and painting,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6803" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6803"></td>
        <td id="LC6803" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">and more sense of the _ensemble_ of a picture. Hans Burkmair</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6804" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6804"></td>
        <td id="LC6804" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">(1473-1531) was the founder of the school, a pupil of Schoengauer,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6805" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6805"></td>
        <td id="LC6805" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">later influenced by Duerer, and finally showing the influence of</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6806" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6806"></td>
        <td id="LC6806" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Italian art. He was not, like Duerer, a religious painter, though doing</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6807" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6807"></td>
        <td id="LC6807" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">religious subjects. He was more concerned with worldly appearance, of</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6808" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6808"></td>
        <td id="LC6808" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">which he had a large knowledge, as may be seen from his illustrations</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6809" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6809"></td>
        <td id="LC6809" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">for engraving. As a painter he was a rather fine colorist, indulging</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6810" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6810"></td>
        <td id="LC6810" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">in the fantastic of architecture but with good taste, crude in</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6811" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6811"></td>
        <td id="LC6811" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">drawing but forceful, and at times giving excellent effects of motion.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6812" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6812"></td>
        <td id="LC6812" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">He was rounder, fuller, calmer in composition than Duerer, but never so</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6813" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6813"></td>
        <td id="LC6813" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">strong an artist.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6814" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6814"></td>
        <td id="LC6814" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6815" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6815"></td>
        <td id="LC6815" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Next to Burkmair comes the celebrated Holbein family. There were four</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6816" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6816"></td>
        <td id="LC6816" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">of them all told, but only two of them, Hans the Elder and Hans the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6817" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6817"></td>
        <td id="LC6817" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Younger, need be mentioned. Holbein the Elder (1460?-1524), after</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6818" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6818"></td>
        <td id="LC6818" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Burkmair, was the best painter of his time and school without being in</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6819" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6819"></td>
        <td id="LC6819" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">himself a great artist. Schoengauer was at first his guide, though he</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6820" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6820"></td>
        <td id="LC6820" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">soon submitted to some Flemish and Cologne influence, and later on</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6821" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6821"></td>
        <td id="LC6821" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">followed Italian form and method in composition to some extent. He was</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6822" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6822"></td>
        <td id="LC6822" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">a good draughtsman, and very clever at catching realistic points of</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6823" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6823"></td>
        <td id="LC6823" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">physiognomy--a gift he left his son Hans. In addition he had some</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6824" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6824"></td>
        <td id="LC6824" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">feeling for architecture and ornament, and in handling was a bit hard,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6825" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6825"></td>
        <td id="LC6825" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">and oftentimes careless. The best half of his life fell in the latter</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6826" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6826"></td>
        <td id="LC6826" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">part of the fifteenth century, and he never achieved the free</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6827" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6827"></td>
        <td id="LC6827" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">painter&#39;s quality of his son.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6828" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6828"></td>
        <td id="LC6828" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6829" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6829"></td>
        <td id="LC6829" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Hans Holbein the Younger (1497-1543) holds, with Duerer, the high place</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6830" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6830"></td>
        <td id="LC6830" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">in German art. He was a more mature painter than Duerer, coming as he</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6831" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6831"></td>
        <td id="LC6831" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">did a quarter of a century later. He was the Renaissance artist of</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6832" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6832"></td>
        <td id="LC6832" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Germany, whereas Duerer always had a little of the Gothic clinging to</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6833" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6833"></td>
        <td id="LC6833" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">him. The two men were widely different in their points of view and in</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6834" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6834"></td>
        <td id="LC6834" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">their work. Duerer was an idealist seeking after a type, a religious</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6835" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6835"></td>
        <td id="LC6835" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">painter, a painter of panels with the spirit of an engraver. Holbein</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6836" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6836"></td>
        <td id="LC6836" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">was emphatically a realist finding material in the actual life about</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6837" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6837"></td>
        <td id="LC6837" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">him, a designer of cartoons and large wall paintings in something of</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6838" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6838"></td>
        <td id="LC6838" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">the Italian spirit, a man who painted religious themes but with little</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6839" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6839"></td>
        <td id="LC6839" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">spiritual significance.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6840" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6840"></td>
        <td id="LC6840" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6841" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6841"></td>
        <td id="LC6841" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">It is probable that he got his first instruction from his father and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6842" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6842"></td>
        <td id="LC6842" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">from Burkmair. He was an infant prodigy, developed early, saw much</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6843" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6843"></td>
        <td id="LC6843" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">foreign art, and showed a number of tendencies in his work. In</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6844" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6844"></td>
        <td id="LC6844" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">composition and drawing he appeared at times to be following Mantegna</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6845" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6845"></td>
        <td id="LC6845" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">and the northern Italians; in brush-work he resembled the Flemings,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6846" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6846"></td>
        <td id="LC6846" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">especially Massys; yet he was never an imitator of either Italian or</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6847" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6847"></td>
        <td id="LC6847" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Flemish painting. Decidedly a self-sufficient and an observing man, he</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6848" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6848"></td>
        <td id="LC6848" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">travelled in Italy and the Netherlands, and spent much of his life in</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6849" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6849"></td>
        <td id="LC6849" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">England, where he met with great success at court as a portrait-painter.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6850" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6850"></td>
        <td id="LC6850" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">From seeing much he assimilated much, yet always remained German,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6851" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6851"></td>
        <td id="LC6851" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">changing his style but little as he grew older. His wall paintings have</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6852" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6852"></td>
        <td id="LC6852" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">perished, but the drawings from them are preserved and show him as an</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6853" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6853"></td>
        <td id="LC6853" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">artist of much invention. He is now known chiefly by his portraits, of</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6854" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6854"></td>
        <td id="LC6854" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">which there are many of great excellence. His facility in grasping</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6855" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6855"></td>
        <td id="LC6855" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">physiognomy and realizing character, the quiet dignity of his</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6856" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6856"></td>
        <td id="LC6856" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">composition, his firm modelling, clear outline, harmonious coloring,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6857" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6857"></td>
        <td id="LC6857" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">excellent detail, and easy solid painting, all place him in the front</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6858" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6858"></td>
        <td id="LC6858" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">rank of great painters. That he was not always bound down to literal</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6859" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6859"></td>
        <td id="LC6859" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">facts may be seen in his many designs for wood-engravings. His portrait</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6860" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6860"></td>
        <td id="LC6860" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">of Hubert Morett, in the Dresden Gallery, shows his art to advantage,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6861" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6861"></td>
        <td id="LC6861" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">and there are many portraits by him of great spirit in England, in the</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6862" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6862"></td>
        <td id="LC6862" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Louvre, and elsewhere.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6863" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6863"></td>
        <td id="LC6863" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6864" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6864"></td>
        <td id="LC6864" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">SAXON SCHOOL: Lucas Cranach (1472-1553) was a Franconian master, who</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6865" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6865"></td>
        <td id="LC6865" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">settled in Saxony and was successively court-painter to three Electors</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6866" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6866"></td>
        <td id="LC6866" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">and the leader of a small local school there. He, perhaps, studied</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6867" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6867"></td>
        <td id="LC6867" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">under Gruenewald, but was so positive a character that he showed no</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6868" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6868"></td>
        <td id="LC6868" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">strong school influence. His work was fantastic, odd in conception and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6869" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6869"></td>
        <td id="LC6869" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">execution, sometimes ludicrous, and always archaic-looking. His type</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6870" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6870"></td>
        <td id="LC6870" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">was rather strained in proportions, not always well drawn, but</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6871" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6871"></td>
        <td id="LC6871" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">graceful even when not truthful. This type was carried into all his</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6872" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6872"></td>
        <td id="LC6872" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">works, and finally became a mannerism with him. In subject he was</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6873" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6873"></td>
        <td id="LC6873" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">religious, mythological, romantic, pastoral, with a preference for</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6874" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6874"></td>
        <td id="LC6874" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">the nude figure. In coloring he was at first golden, then brown, and</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6875" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6875"></td>
        <td id="LC6875" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">finally cold and sombre. The lack of aerial perspective and shadow</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6876" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6876"></td>
        <td id="LC6876" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">masses gave his work a queer look, and he was never much of a</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6877" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6877"></td>
        <td id="LC6877" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">brushman. His pictures were typical of the time and country, and for</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6878" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6878"></td>
        <td id="LC6878" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">that and for their strong individuality they are ranked among the most</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6879" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6879"></td>
        <td id="LC6879" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">interesting paintings of the German school. Perhaps his most</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6880" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6880"></td>
        <td id="LC6880" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">satisfactory works are his portraits. Lucas Cranach the Younger</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6881" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6881"></td>
        <td id="LC6881" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">(1515-1586) was the best of the elder Cranach&#39;s pupils. Many of his</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6882" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6882"></td>
        <td id="LC6882" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">pictures are attributed to his father. He followed the elder closely,</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6883" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6883"></td>
        <td id="LC6883" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">but was a weaker man, with a smoother brush and a more rosy color.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6884" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6884"></td>
        <td id="LC6884" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">Though there were many pupils the school did not go beyond the Cranach</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6885" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6885"></td>
        <td id="LC6885" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">family. It began with the father and died with the son.</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6886" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6886"></td>
        <td id="LC6886" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6887" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6887"></td>
        <td id="LC6887" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">[Illustration: FIG. 92.--LEIBL. IN CHURCH.]</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6888" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6888"></td>
        <td id="LC6888" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line"></td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6889" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6889"></td>
        <td id="LC6889" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">SEVENTEENTH AND EIGHTEENTH CENTURIES: These were unrelieved centuries</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6890" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6890"></td>
        <td id="LC6890" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">of decline in German painting. After Duerer, Holbein, and Cranach had</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6891" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6891"></td>
        <td id="LC6891" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">passed there came about a senseless imitation of Italy, combined with</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
        <td id="L6892" class="blob-num js-line-number" data-line-number="6892"></td>
        <td id="LC6892" class="blob-code blob-code-inner js-file-line">an equally senseless imitation of detail in nature that produced</td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
